A better view of the opera house.... But that's pretty much it. Don't get me wrong, it is nice up there, but there space is tight, and if you have already climbed the bridge you won't see anything new. Having said that, unlike the bridge climb, you will have your camera so you can take photos.

Anticlimactic after the Bridge Climb. We did the Bridge Climb in the morning and our ticket got us into the Pylon as well. What was great was that we could take pictures of the bridge and where we went in the morning. Cameras are not allowed on the climb. There were good exhibits inside the Pylon.

Our oz trip. If you dont have the bottle to walk across the bridge top , as many do, there is a cheaper and easier tourist trip to go up the pylon to the look out, as a ferist og heights my wife and daughter went up and assured me it was brilliant

Great viewpoint for Sydney Harbour. Great viewpoint in order to see in all directions. Watch the ship traffic or look for your favorite spots. Tip - if you climb the Sydney Harbour Bridge, you get a free pass to climb the pylon (within 30 days). Definitely better than paying (again).

Great place to watch climbers on the Bridge. My husband did the Bridge Climb and after leaving him at the Bridge starting point, I went a short walk partly over the Bridge and then went up the Pylon Lookout. The 180 degree views of the harbour were great and I got some good photos. I had intended just waiting to see if I could spot him start his climb (it's about an hour before they appear on the Bridge) and then meet him back at base when he'd finished. However I was amazed how easy it was to spot him and follow his progress. There were several others on the lookout doing the same as me and watching people they knew doing the climb. In fact there was quite a comradely between us and I ended watching him climb up and come back down, and the time flew by. Add to that I managed to get the most amazing pictures of him and met some interesting fellow holiday makers.

64 steps and a short walk to a better view than multi-millionaires get. The Bridge was built around the time of the Great Depression but it is a great example of vision and co-operation. Its design was simple but extremely elegant. There are some stairs just off Cumberland Street (up from the Shangri-La hotel with its 36th level views of the Bridge - worth paying $8 for a small mineral water for). Now the adventurous can pay for a Bridge Climb guided tour but we more timid souls just need to walk 64 steps of a brick pylon and we are a the podium level. A short walk on a concrete path through some lovely trees takes up to the steel part of the bridge and then a few more steps to the look-out in one of the main four pylons of the bridge. The view of the water is great and the Opera House is right in front. You can't see the heads (but the Manly Ferry will do that for you) or the vista of Sydney from "on high" but you are at the same level as the top of a good sized cruise ship. It's all free to this point and you can keep walking across to Milson's Point or do as we did and meander back through the rocks area to Wynyard Station and take the train to Milson's Point and back again for views of the west side of the Harbour.
A fantastic view. An excellent 360 degree view of the Sydney harbour. A bridge view but for much cheaper! over all a great place to visit

Stunning views!. As other reviews have said, BridgeClimb offers the best experience and views, but for only AUD$13 the Lookout Pylon is fabulous. There is a continual large screen film show depicting the history of the bridge as well as a small exhibition with photographs and information. But the best bit is at the top of the stairs where you can go outside on a viewing platform and look across to the Opera House, Circular Quay, The Rocks, Luna Park and see the small groups climbing the Harbour Bridge itself. Just fantastic, especially on a sunny day! There is no time limit to how long you can stay and admire the view either. Be sure to look in the gift shop on the way up or down as some of the merchandise is very reasonably priced. I found a T-shirt for only AUD$9.95 so bought two in different colours! The staff are helpful and friendly too. A "must do" whilst in Sydney and suitable for all ages and fitness levels.

A Perfect Alternative to the Bridge Climb. If you've climbed the Sydney Harbour Bridge (which I have) or checked out the prices for it, you know that it is very expensive. Climbing the Pylon Lookout is a perfect alternative to the larger expense, or also if you have less time for this activity. Granted, it does not have the 360 degree views, and does not go as high .. 87 m instead of the bridge's 134 m. However, it is still higher than the Opera House at 67 m and gives you an amazing view of the Sydney Harbour and the girder construction of the Bridge itself.The blue granite construction of the 4 pylons is for looks alone, as they do not provide a foundation for the bridge. The granite is supposed to have some special healing power and was brought to the site at one-fourth the cost of the entire bridge.The pylon you climb is the one that is on the south-east corner of the bridge footings. There are several sets of stairs leading to the actual climb area from the Circular Quay. Cost of the climb is $13 per person. the Pylon is open from 10 am to 5 pm. There are several sets of stairs inside the pylon before you get to the admissions area.... by then you are more than one-third of the way up! The climb is advertised as 200 steps, and it probably is in total from street level, but the actual number inside the pylon from the bridge deck level is less than that... I thought about 130.At every stair level (I believe there are six long, wide staircases) there are several displays, and a major historical picture and write-up display of the bridge construction when you get to the admissions area. There you will also find souvenirs and snacks for sale. You can climb as slowly or as quickly as you are able. There are a lot of rest opportunities along the way. The viewing PRIZE is at the top! And what a view it is! You can go right around the pylon that has a narrow walkway with a waist-height wall, and plexi-glass above that. Views of the Opera House, the Bridge, the City and the Harbour are the best. Westward views are still good, obviously not the full view as during the bridge climb... but there is less to see both west and north. And, with this climb, you can take your camera!If you can climb the Pylon, it is a great alternative to the huge expense of the Bridge Climb, and pretty near just as awesome!

A great view if you're short on time. Not sure about the cost of the lookout entry, as we got free tickets because we did the bridge climb earlier - can't comment on value for money.However, the walk up the Pylon is well worth it, with a very rewarding view, and well worth doing. I'm 53 but quite fit, and had no issue with the climb effort.A limited history of the bridge construction is provided as you climb, which was OK, but I was surprised at how few historic photos and materials were actually shown here. Surely they have stacks of this sort of material in the State archives....

The bridge when you are short on time and/or $$$. A little hard to find on foot.. not the best signage but eventually followed our noses and found the right way to go. Not overly strenuous, some initial steps and then some history and a little gift shop to browse in before ascending to the top for the view. It's spectacular. Great 360 degree views of Sydney and the harbour. Windy, but great photo op.We learnt alot about the building of the bridge and overall found this a worthwhile place to visit

Great views for a faction of the price of the bridge climb.. I was in Sydney for NYE and the Harbour Bridge is one of those iconic must-dos of Sydney. What I didn't realize at first is there are two different ways to see the bridge. One is the Pylon Lookout. Very affordable, something like $13 AUD per person. It gives great views of the bridge and harbour. A must do.The other is the Bridge Climb, where you actually get to climb to the arch of the bridge. Being their at peak season, the price was even higher than off peak season, which you'd expect, but the cost was $270 AUD. I'm sure the bridge climb is amazing, but the value of the Pylon Lookout won out over the much more expense bridge climb.

Great View of Sydney Harbour. I've climbed the stairs to the top of the Pylon lookout on the Harbour Bridge several times. It offers you an amazing view of the Opera House, Sydney Harbour, and the groups hiking the Bridge Climb. Great spot for photographers to get some memorable shots.
Worth the climb. 13 dollars only to enter, but it's worth it. I've done the Bridge Climb and the Pylon lookout. however, for travellers who cannot afford the bridge climb, this is a must do!
Wow. A nice walk , quite a few steps but worth it when get to top . Another great lookout point from different angle of bridge and opera house.

Better than Centrepoint. We decided to do this with the kids before we went to Centrepoint Tower as it was "The Bridge"... Inexpensive, fantastic views across the Harbour and city and informative about building the bridge and the attitudes behind it. Both my husband and I had done Centrepoint on previous visits and decided to not bother after the Pylon Lookout. We followed it up with a walk across the bridge to Milson's Point. A hidden gem in the tourism catalogue.

The best $13 you can spend in Sydney . 200 steps up to a 360 degree viewing platform for stunning views of Sydney City, the beautiful opera house & harbour, surrounding bays and, of course, an aerial view of the harbour bridge itself. Topped off with an interesting historical exhibition about the construction of the bridge. It's an easy climb and well worth it. A hidden gem and we would thoroughly recommend it to everyone.

Fantastic Sydney views!. This place is amazing! It's a south-east pylon of the Sydney Harbour Bridge.A viewing terrace at the top gives you great views of The Bridge and the city, including awesome photo opportunities for the Sydney Opera House shots.The pylon platform has no bars or any other wire barriers so it's a great place for video panoramas too.It's great alternative to a hyper-expensive Bridge Climb tour.I was there in February 2015 and it cost me only AU $13It's 20x less than a Bridge Climb, but I digress.You can stay at the terrace as long as you want. When I got there a light rain stopped me from filming and photography but I've waited it out, in a covered building at the top. Easy.The views are breath-taking! The Opera House, the city, the Bay - just fantastic! You need to remember you're at a top of a high object and there is wind there. Howling, merciless wind, so don't count on any audio recordings if you're shooting a video, and don't wear any loose hats, scarves or any loose wardrobe. It will fly away and you will never see it again. LOLTo get there you may take a few different routes. It's accessible to bikers but not by a car. If you just want to walk there on foot, take the route I chose:Take George street north, to Argyle Street.Turn left (west) at Argyle and watch carefully for an entrance. You will see white apartment building on one side of the street. Take the other side. JUST BEFORE you go under first overpass, look for a small stone arch-way in the wall. It's marked "Argyle Stairs", in the stone letters overhead. Take the stairs and follow the signs to the Bridge Pylon. Look it up on Google Street View - you can see it there. On the way back you might stop at The Rocks. It's a small park at the end of the George Street and Hickson Way. More awesome views of the Opera House and the Bridge.  I'm not posting any photos of the Pylon here. There are hundreds of them already available. It's a very interesting spot in Sydney and it won't break your budget.

Commanding view of the Sydney Harbor & Opera House. Our time was limited in Sydney, so we decided to walk to this Pylon Lookout and not do the full on bridge climb. We found it was still exhilarating to get up to the lookout. You are over the bridge and you do see the climbers as they go up from where you are. We could use our own camera here, you can't on the Climb Tour. The views of the Opera House and Harbor are breathtaking! They had a video of the making of the bridge inside and they did a nice job with the information boards and artifacts they kept to show some of the history of making the bridge. They have a small souvenir shop inside, too.. No small feat, the making of this bridge. Our boys 12 and 15 enjoyed this and preferred not to climb the bridge. They wanted to splurge on going to the Backstage Tour with Breakfast in the Green Rm. at the Opera House instead. So this was a great option for us. The fee is about $13 AUD per adult and less for kids.
Great view. We did this because I am too afraid of hieghts. So we chose this tour thinking it may be a little rough with all the stairs, but it was not too dificult.

Cheapest Viewing Attraction in Sydney - Must See. If you a looking for that wonderful view of Sydney and surrounds this is a must see. $13 (Adults) $6.50 (Children) to climb the top of south-east Pylon of the Harbour Bridge with a 360 degree viewing platform at the top. Great photography opportunities and views to the Blue Mountains on a clear day. Great exhibition on the history of the bridge as well. Toilets available.
Breathtaking view. After working your way to the top, via good historical posters, photos and displays taken during the construction of the bridge, the view is stunning and breathtaking.

Oops, I meant to post here instead of Sydney Harbor Bridge.. Pylon lookout is well worth the price. Only 200-something steps and a lot cheaper than the 1,300 steps and big bucks for the bridge climb. Still got great pics of the harbor, Opera House, etc. Do this climb.

A must-do in Sydney!. Definitely a must when you're in Sydney: Going up to the Pylon Lookout. Awesome view from up there, you can see Circular Quay, the opera house and of course the bridge itself. Highly recommended!

Better than Bridge Climb. I love this look out. You can take your camera and get some amazing shots. There are a lot of steps so difficult with strollers. However you can take it at your own pace so it is very manageable for people of all fitness levels. You learn a lot about the bridge and its history. It also has a good souvenir shop. Well worth the entry price.

Great view. No doubt its a great view and not substantially different to the Bridge climb view, so if you do the bridge climb make it for the experience rather than the view as you get pretty much the same view from here at a fraction of the price.But if we are playing that game do you need to pay $13 to come up here at all? Why not just check the view out from the bridge level walkway for free?That's a fair point and whilst the pylon gives you a bit more elevation that isn't the point of difference to the walkway level. The point of difference is the view of the bridge itself. From the Pylon you get an impressive semi-top down view of the bridge. From the walkway level your view is a freeway crossing the bridge!

The budget bridge climb. For a small fee you get to understand the history of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Then go outside for the same 360 degree million dollar views that you get on the Bridge Climb. There is some climbing but it is very manageable. The advantage being as you don't have to book you can wait for a fine day to experience it.

Good view of the harbour. If your not too sure about climbing the Harbour bridge then this is a good choice. Excellent views and the history of the bridge turned out to be very interesting. There is a good shop selling quite interesting items far superior than your usual souvenir shops.
great views and easy walk up. we were offered free entry as part of the bridge climb, it is well worth taking this option - amazing 360 degree views of sydney

Amazing Views.... Without having to spend the big money on the bridge climb and you can take your own pictures... this is a great option to see two of the icons in the harbor...the bridge and the opera house, PLUS you get to see the museum inside the pylon!!!
Breath taking . A breath taking vieuw over Sydney! Admission price for a student for was fine 8.50$ I think the price for a adult is a bit more expensive. But totally worth going up there!

Beautiful views.. Certainly worth the entrance fees. You'll have to take a bunch of sets of stairs up, but they are wide and pretty easy.
Beautiful 360 degree views at the top. You can see the Opera House, the harbor and all the tall buildings of the CBD. Highly recommended.

Tip of the world view. If you can't climb the bridge then this is a must the views are spectacular and can see the climbers on the bridge. It is steps only but easy enough for young children. The information provided and video great to know the history
Bucket List. Enjoyable and very well organised. Helen - our guide - was extremely good. Recommend going about 6 pm so get day and night views.

Awesome views. The 360 view of Sydney is breathtaking. It also gives you a good idea where everything is with computer guides every few meters to help orientate yourself to the different attractions, parks, museums, stadiums that make Sydney what it is

Amazing views of sydndy. This was one of my biggest highlights of our trip, the walk there was amazing and the walk up the stairs was a lot easier then I thought. Views were spectacular and the price was beyond worth it, I still can't believe how cheap it was to see similar views to the climb. I also couldn't believe how quiet it was visiting on a sunny summers day in the school holidays, there was at least two other families up there at the same time, I guess the walk and the fact it isn't free must just turn people off yet it was so worth it!
great view. when in town, absolute must to visit. can easily be reached by foot when in the city center, so feel free to enjoy

Next best thing to the bridge climb. If you dont do heights but want the view try the pylon view at the south east bridge tower. Its low cost aud13 and a short 200 step climb to the top where the views are terrific. You caan learn the history of the bridge and see where the bridge climbers climb!
Beautiful view. Nice lookout with amazing view of opear house and sydney harbour. Also, provides a lot of information about the bridge, how it was built, etc.
Sweeping Views of Sydney. Take the time and make the effort to venture up this pylon if you are in the area, the views are spectacular on a clear day and will not disappoint.

Great way to see the views without climbing the bridge..... It's a bit of a trek to the top as there are lots of stairs just to get up to the bridge itself then to the top of the pylon. There are no lifts so would not be accessible to wheelchair users or those that struggle with stairs. Lots of interesting information on how the bridge was built along the way as you ascend. Gift shop and toilets at about half way. Great way to spend an hour or so to see the views without having to climb the bridge or pay over the odds as at $13 it's a bargain and you get to take your own pictures too !

Amazing Views. The pylon lookout is located on the southern pylon on the Circular Quay side of the Harbour Bridge. You climb some narrow stairs initially, and then come to the first level where you pay $13 for entry. They have many interesting pieces of history showing how the bridge was constructed, how long it took, cost etc. When you reach the top the views are amazing. We were watching people doing the bridge climb and waving to them!For the small cost, this is highly recommended as the views of the Opera House, Harbour, Sydney skyline etc are simply amazing.

Short free climb with fantastic view. It was very cold on the day we went for a walk on Sydney bridge. Simple walk up some steps behind The Rock and we got a magnificent view of Sydney Harbour! A must do if you have time to spare!

It's worth the walk. This lookout is located in one of the structures of the Harbour Bridge, so the only way to get to it is walking.... but it's worth it! Once you climb the stairs and it's finally at the top, the view is amazing! There are information about the view in the glasses along the lookout and you can recognize the main attractions of the city easily! Nice place for hundreds of pictures!

Great alternative to bridge climb. We climbed the pylon lookout and can't believe what a good alternative it is to the expensive and regulated bridge climb. Not only was it a small fraction of the cost, there was no booking required, we could take cameras, backpacks etc to get wonderful 360 deg views. Went twice round to get more enjoyment! Also an interesting museum with heaps to educate and enlighten. Best kept secret! Not quite the height of harbour bridge but as close as damn it!

Affordable and more doable than the HB climb. I'd always wanted to walk across the Harbour Bridge, and to find this little museum and lookout was a delightful surprise. The 200 stairs have plenty of opportunities to rest. The views from the top are lovely, especially on the glorious day we had.

The affordable sydney "bridge climb". If spending 200+ dollars to climb a bridge doesn't make sense to you or you simply dont have the budget, then this one is just perfect for you.It's as good as the bridge climb minus the climb and the thrill. The view is just as magnificent, plus a lot more cheaper ($13 for adult).

Great place with awesome views and free!!!. Definitely worth a visit if you have time. A little tricky to work your way there, but ask locals and they will guide you (shops and the like). The view is great especially on a sunny day, and for a free attraction, you can't beat it - amazing views straight down Sydney Harbour toward the Heads and over the Opera House. You won't get the iconic photos (as you are on one of the major ones), but great all the same.

Nice view. Admission to the pylon is free with a bridge climb ticket. It features beautiful views and interesting information about construction of the bridge. There are LOTS of steps to the top, so it's definitely not handicap accessible.

One of the best views in Sydney. Where else could you get a view over Circular Quay, the Op House and city, see a museum of the making of the bridge and a short movie that make the hair on the back of your neck stand up - for about $11. Fantastic experience & value!!

Free if you climb the bridge.. When you climb the bridge you cannot take a camera or phone. So climb the pylon and then you get an opportunity to take pictures from up high. And you get a very good history of the bridge construction.

Easy city views. Whether you have done the bridge climb or not, the Pylon Lookout offers great views both across the city and back toward the Parramatta River. It is cheap, easy to access, and you can stay as long as you like. Make sure you take your camera!

Interesting . I did the bridge climb a couple of days before and so had a free entry. Even if you've done the climb it's worth going to see, it shouldn't take more than an hour and you get some stunning views from the viewing platform at the top.
Great Alternative to Bridge Climb. Save some coin, bring your own camera and still have excellent views. There's even a museum halfway up and plenty of rest/sit spots on the way up.

Panoramic view Opera McMahons and Sydney skyline. ample cheap parking on weekends on argyle st which is a 15 minute rigorous walk to the pylon lookout. You will need to walk up the stairs to the level of harbour bridge from cumberland st. As you enter the pylon lookout, another set of steep stairs. The view is certainly breathtaking and a paradise for a photographer with a wideangle lens. It closes down by 10 min to 5pm so reach there on time and keep atleast half an hour to view and click. A short movie just before you start walking down the stairs is worth watching. Go in the evening to witness the shadow of the harbour bridge falling on the sea. A must do for someone who cant afford to climb the bridge!

Interesting history plus great views. This is a fairly cheap attraction and well worth the entrance fee. There is a small but interesting exhibition about the bridge's history, with an audio visual presentation. However, the best part is the open balcony with spectacular views of the bridge, harbour and back into Sydney centre.

A gem. Unexpected gem on the bridge. Beautiful views and informative exhibition. Not well advertised yet probably some of the best views you can get and at a fraction of the cost of the bridge walk. Should be promoted better

Worth the stair climb - fabulous views. We decided to take this trip over doing the bridge climb as we had learned the views were awesome without the expense. We were also able to take and use our own cameras which was a bonusThe stairs are not so bad and the fee of about $13 is worth it.There are photos and also lots of information boards to show the construction detail.On the level below the outside area there is a small gift shopThe outside has a high wall so there is no danger of falling over, you have 360 degree views of the whole harbour and seem to be moreorless on a level with some of those climbing the bridge itselfIt was a lovely sunny but windy day, the parapet helped to keep the wind at bay

A gem hidden in plain sight. I am amazed that I had to come across this great place by accident, and that no one had recommended it to me (nor did I read anything about it in the numerous tourist brochures), as it turned out to be one of the highlights of our trip to Sydney. It is an excellent little museum, presenting artefacts and fascinating information about the bridge and its history, but more importantly, the 360º view from the platform (about 90m above sea level) is second to none. As a vantage point it's a photographer's dream. If climbing the bridge is not your thing (for financial, time, vertigo or other reasons), getting up the Pylon Lookout is the best way to admire the beauty of Darling Harbour. There is a small fee, but those were the best spent $13. Do not miss it, it is wonderful!
lovely view. i took snaps from here but unfortunately due to all the world problems this place had been closed off.amazing pictures to be taken from here

Pylon Lookout - Fantastic Views. Walking West from Circular Quay:A 15 minute walk to the Bridge Pylon Lookout (which is in The Rocks)You can continue on afterwards, and walk across the harbor bridge from the Pylon lookout to Milsons Point.Then, take the ferry or train from the Milson's Point ferry dock or train station back to CQ ferry dock or train station.Or, take the ferry from Milson's Point to Darling Harbor.Another option is to have lunch at Ripples, before heading back to CQ.O,r have lunch at the Rocks Market before the walk.The cost is $A13. Open 10AM till 5PM.The bridge, Opera House & Royal Botanic Gardens can be done in a single dayFantastic photos of the Opera House, & CQ can be had.

Spectacular, from bottom to top !. This is such a Sydney thing to do ! Not just for people visiting our beautiful city but also for the locals. The South Eastern pylon is not only a superb look-out over the harbour and city skyline, its also a museum dedicated to the construction of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Full of original photographs, drawings, stories and memorabilia this is a morning or afternoon well spent with the added bonus of a fantastic view when you get to the top.Not to be missed !

Stunning views and good value... Highly recommend this. No need to dress up in special gear. Stairs to climb but lots of rest points between each stage. Interesting display about history of bridge with fascinating facts. The courage of the chaps who built this in days before Health & Safety is staggering...Views from top amazing. Sideways views of the bridge and fantastic views of harbour, all the ships crisscrossing it, the Opera House and the contrast between the historic buildings of the Rocks area and modern CBD skyscrapers. .all these make for a thoroughly worthwhile visit. If you are a concession (e.g. pensioner) it's even better value by the way, I think $8 or similar?

A nice view of the Sydney harbour. If you want to enjoy the view of Sydney harbour, do come here.it is in the Rocks area and easy, just follow directions pr enquirer at the information centre. The staff is very friendly and polite. There is a market when we were there on the weekend and stores sells lovely souvenir and yummy food. Have your camera with you to shoot nice view of the harbour

Fantastic Views. I desperately wanted to do the climb over the bridge but I have a terrible fear of heights so decided to do the Pylon Lookout climb instead. I am so glad I did. The views were absolutely stunning and I took some amazing photos. It was great to see all the old photos of the building of the bridge. So interesting.

Recommended for all visitors to Sydney!. For just a small fee (around $10) you get a great background on the building of the bridge, the controversy at its opening and probably the best view of Sydney Harbour (bring your camera!). The view from the top is stunning and a very different view of the arch of the bridge.

Awesome View. Amazing views of Sydney and the Harbor, and views back onto the Opera house. There is a charge to get up the pylon, however you can walk across the bridge from one side to the other for free, catch the train at Milsons point back into the city if you dont want to walk back again..

A cheap alternative to the Bridge climb. If the Bridge climb is too expensive, then the Pylon lookout is a much cheaper alternative. Priced at just $13 for an adult, the views are similar to the Bridge Climb, and you won't be so windswept afterwards. The small attraction has a small exhibition about the Bridge and a film to watch after you have been to the top. There are steps, however the views are worth it and if the lookout is not busy, then you can spend plenty of time recovering whilst enjoying your location. The walk from Circular Quay on to the Bridge is also enjoyable. I think this is a very worthwhile attraction and would recommend it to anyone.

This tour is $13. It is not '$158 and up'. Tripadvisor should correct the misleading price information tagged to this attraction which would scare off many potential visitors.I am a local, and live close by. This tour is $13. It is not '$158 and up' as misleadingly implied by the advertisement inserted at the top of this section and next to the attraction listing in 'Top Things to Do in Sydney'.I suspect that people are being mislead intentionally because this government-owned (but 'Bridge Climb' managed) attraction is between 1/10th and 1/20th of the price of the competing commercial 'Bridge Climb' attraction. The pylon lookout offers 360 degree views almost as good as the top of the bridge. You can take your own camera and linger as long as you like, which you cannot do on 'Bridge Climb'.

Go after your Bridge Climb!. Your Bridge Climb Sydney ticket comes with free admission, take advantage of it! When you do the bridge climb, you are not allowed to bring a camera and if you walk up to the pylon, you have a similar view with your own camera. Theres also some historical information which is interesting. It definitely completes your climbing experience. You can also see people climbing so you know what you looked like!

Worth to go. The admission fee was already inclusive in the Bridge Climb package. It took around 15-minute walk from The Rock to Pylon Lookout via Bridge Stair. You could learn more details, like history & construction, from the exhibition here. Unfortunately, it rained heavily on my day of visit, so I couldn't go out of the top open-air for the fantastic view of Sydney Harbour.

What a view!. We were visiting Sydney earlier in the week and walked to the Pylon lookout. On the way up the pylon inside are many photos and facts about the building of the harbour bridge. The view from the top is 360 degrees breathtaking. We were there for a very long time just taking everything in. On the way out was a short film about the construction which was very interesting. Would recommend to everyone visiting Sydney for the first time.

Great views of the harbour. This may not have the thrill of climbing the bridge but the views from the top of the pylon are very good. The view to the Opera House is especially good. The climb to reach the bridge is actually more arduous than the climb up the Pylon which is a series of gentle stairs. The top of the Pylon is about 89 metres above the water. Inside the Pylon there is a small gift shop and there is also a video presentation about the history of the bridge.

Bridge view. I found this to be the best option than climbing than climbing the bridge. while the Harbour bridge is beautiful, I like the Brooklyn bridge better. That was why my friend and I decided not to do the bridge climb. Additionally, I thought it was pretty expensive to do so. But if you just walk on the entrance of the bridge, you will find this Pylon lookout. Reasonable entrance fee and they have a lot of information about the story of how the bridge was built.
Best Views of Sydney. The best value and well worth the climb to the top, $23 for 2 adults and 1 child and a museum and movie about the building of the bridge, a must do when visiting Sydney

Great views of Harbour Bridge, Opera House, Circular Quay, and Harbour. The Sydney Habour Bridge has four pylons – large cement towers atop the foundations for the four main bearings (two at each end) that anchor the bridge; and, one of these, the South East Pylon is accessible to the public and has a lookout atop it. This is a great companion activity, or alternative if time and budget demand, to the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. The top of the pylon, at 87 meters (285 feet) above the harbor, offers great views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge (up close), the Opera House, the Circular Quay, and the Harbour itself. The entrance fee is modest at AU$13 for people over 13 years in age. It is open every day until 5p. There is a bit of a climb (200 stairs), but exhibits and stops break up the climb if needed. Since the Harbour Bridge Climb does not, for obvious reasons relating to falling objects, permit cameras atop the bridge – this, then, is the best alternative for taking photographs from a similar vantage point. The views are outstanding. There is only one pylon that is open to public to climb – again, that is the South East Pylon – and you can access this from The Rocks area, by taking stairs off Cumberland (which runs alongside and parallel to the bridge) on the southeast side, near Argyle Street. Climb the stairs and then walk towards the span on the sidewalk along the expressway until you encounter the pylon.

Best spot to see the Bridge and the Opera House! (BEST PRICE). We were debating to do the Bridge Climb verse the Pylon lookout and when we saw the price different AND the time difference we decided to do the Pylon lookout. We didn't have 2-3 hours to complete the Bridge Climb as we were only there for two days so we paid $13 for the Pylon lookout and it was exactly what we wanted! Great view of the Bridge and the Opera House. You can't go wrong with this stop! Do know that there are stairs involved.

Great Views – Super Cheap. For those who don’t want to spend the 250 AUD for the bridge walk, the pylon is a great alternative. At less than 10% the price, you get some great 360-degree views of the city and some of the bridge history in the displays inside the pylon. It’s not comparable to walking to the top of the bridge, they are different experiences, but this is definitely worth doing.

Brilliant view of the Harbour. It's 200 steps to the top of the Pylon but the rewards are fantastic. The view out over the harbour is breathtaking and it's well worth the $13 admission. The best time of day to visit for photographs of the harbour is in the afternoon when the sun is behind you.

Great views. The climb maybe hard for some. Views are in incredible with 360 degree views of Sydney.
The reading material is thorough and informative. A cheaper alternative to the bridge climb.

A Different Perspective On Sydney. For decades tourists and locals alike have taken to walking the few stairs to the top of the Pylon Lookout, another of the fabulous attractions that are an integral part of the Sydney Harbor Bridge. There is only one pylon open to the public and it provides you with a knockout view of downtown Sydney, Circular Quay, the Sydney Opera House and, of course, Sydney Harbor. If you find yourself anywhere near the "Coat Hanger" you must take time to check this lookout.

Awesome Views. The climb up the tower looked a little daunting but it was broken up along the way with mini exhibits. Once at the top the views were incredible and we would highly recommend this to anyone who visits or lives in Sydney

"Who Knew"". This is a great history lesson on the bridge and the facts of how the bridge was built was amazing- my wife and i enjoyed it immensely and so did the other people on the pylon when we were there.Cheap and well worth it.

Affordable Views. Definitely worth it! I'm so glad we did this! It gave us a really cool 360 view of Sydney and the Harbour. Also, it is much more affordable than spending money to do the bridge climb or the tower eye.

Inexpensive and awesome!. For those unwilling to fork out a few hundred dollars for the Bridgeclimb (which is a wonderful experience), or those with a fear of heights, then this is an AMAZING alternative.For around AUD$13.00, you climb one of the historic pylons, and get to the top where you have a 360º view of Sydney, the harbour, and distant suburbs.You have to be fairly confident with climbing around 10 flights of stairs, but don't worry if you have a fear of heights. The stairs are secure, and inside. And even once outside, the parapet / balcony wall is so high, that you will not have any vertigo or fear. It is IMPOSSIBLE, even standing on the benches to get a better view, to even raise your chest above the solid wall - it's VERY safe and secure. And this is coming from someone who's PETRIFIED of heights!Great photo opportunities abound - especially during fine weather, but it's actually suitable during all weather - except maybe pouring rain.Probably the only thing would be an update to the gift shop (most things are a bit twee / tacky) and perhaps even a small cafe on that level, before heading up to the main viewing level. Hell, someone could make a fair bit of money with evening dining and viewing options!

Couldn't find the place. I got bored of trying to find this place and ended up just heading towards the bridge. When I did find the entrance, it was clear to me that the view from the bridge was already pretty amazing and the pylon was only about another 25 metres higher, and it wasn't worth the entrance fee when I was already on top of the Sydney Harbour Bridge with amazing views!

Don't pass-up this history and view. The entry fee is relatively modest and yet it provides great views of the harbor including the Opera House and Circular Quay. Within the pylon are exhibits of artifacts and photos from the construction. No, this public works project did not happen overnight or without political drama but as you will see it has been well worth the investment. The bridge walk is quite good but pricey and this is a fine alternative but only open from 10AM to 5PM. If you do do the bridge walk you will get a certificate to visit the Pylon as well.
Awesome. The views from here are awesome. Some really good photos can be taken from here. Views are similar to the Bridge Climb.
Views as good as from the top of the Harbour Bridge.. If your scared of heights and can't do the bridge then maybe this one is for you, great history and photos of the bridge.

Something else to do at the Bridge.. Well worth a visit if you don't have time to do the bridge climb. The views from the top are spectacular. Spend as long as you like taking pictures of the Opera house, the Bridge and Cityscape. Admission to the Pylon Lookout is included in the Bridge Climb price.There is also a museum inside with lots of facts and figures about the Bridge construction. If there are school parties visiting let them go to the lookout first and you can watch a video in the small theatre until they come down.

Breath taking Views. “A must do for any visitor to Sydney” Once you have reached the top the views are simpy stunning and you can see all Sydney has to offer in all directions, it really is an amzing picture and the perfect spot for you to take your photographs.

Must Watch in Sydney, Worth the Spend. Step back into the history of the Sydney Harbour Bridge - Its beginnings, its planning and construction, its vision. Relive the magic of the opening celebration, and enjoy panoramic views from the original Sydney lookout. Come and see the fantastic views of the city, the harbour and the world famous icon - the Sydney Harbour Bridge!There are 200 stairs to the Pylon Lookout™, 87 metres above mean sea level, but on the way up there are 3 levels of exhibits where you will discover the history and construction of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, the men who built it, and the vision of JJC Bradfield, chief engineer.

Amazing view!. If you want an amazing view over the Sydney Harbour.. This is a very good place to go! The entry is for a student around 8$ and you get a beautiful view! You can see the Sydney Opera House and see the Harbour Bridge from a very nice point of view. Great place for pictures and being a typical tourist :)

Pylons Or Not, Great View From Sydney Harbor Bridge. The view from the Sydney Harbor Bridge is one not to miss. If you are will to spend the time and money you could do a bridge walk to the top or partway up. If you don't have that time or money then you could check out the Pylon Lookout. Even cheaper is the free and still spectacular views from the walkway across the bridge. One way or another though, make your way up to the bridge and enjoy the view. It is absolutely fantastic.

Full of history and a great view. I got a free ticket to the pylon lookout after I did the bridge climb but it is not expensive to get into anyway. It gives you a great lookout across the harbour and if you are not intending to do the climb it takes you closer to the architecture than just walking across the bridge. The museum is very informative and there is a video on loop near the end which shows you in old black and white photos how the bridge was built. There are a few steps to the top so be prepared!

Great view, perfect lookout point. Is definitely worth climbing up the stairs (not that physically demanding anyway). The view of the Opera House and Harbour Brigde is just so stunning especially under the clear blue sky. Take as many photos as you like and no one will ever stop you. The video show is short but nice, very informative and interesting to learn how the Harbour Bridge was built back then. Definitely worth the visit, and if you like to take loads of photos or selfies, make sure you don't miss out this Pylon Lookout.

Better than climbing. I have been up here a few times when I visit Sydney for the views. It has a spectacular open air viewing platform at the top of the south west pylon over the Harbour Bridgs. There is an entrance fee and stairs to climb but it is well worth it. An excellent vantage point to watch cruise ships leave if it is still open at the time. There is museum displays in the pylon as well as a looping video about the history of the bridge being built.

Fantastic! Great photo opportunity!. If you would like the perfect view of Sydney Harbour try the Pylon climb. I had taken the zillion steps to the top 20 years ago and I remember being blown away by the view at the top. The steps can be a challenge but well worth the effort. My second climb (remembering I'm 20 years older and less fit haha) was just as spectacular as my first experience.Although its not on par with the Harbour Bridge climb its still excellent....perfect for tourists on a limited budget or for locals as a reminder of what a beautiful city we live in.I recommend you recuperate with a cold beer at one of the beautiful pubs at The Rocks!
Short stay Sydney. Excellent lookout over the harbour of sydney and the operahouse. With good weather you can make excellent foto's and have a nice view over the river.

Affordable, great view. We received a ticket to the Pylon Lookout as part of our Bridge Climb experience. We loved it! It's part museum, part work out (lots of stairs!) and a great view. If you're purchasing a ticket it's much more reasonable than bridge climb, too! Tip: if you are doing Bridge Climb, have a friend go up the pylon and take photos of you - they have the perfect vantage point as you ascend the bridge. If we has realized it was there, we would have had someone do this for us! I'd recommend going up the lookout as you walk across the bridge.

A must while in Sydney.. We chose not to do the bridge climb for fiscal reasons but very glad we went up the pylon. The view is just as high anyway and cost just $12. The museum and displays tell you everything you need to know about the construction and design, and told a lot that I didn't already know or thought I even wanted to! Very interesting. One of the best views in Sydney. I could have spent much longer up there soaking it in. Would definitely recommend.I'm not one for gift shops either but I must reference how reasonably price it was, and not full of tat. We found the entrance to be a chore to find though - look into where it is before you set off!
A must do for any visitor to Sydney. Well worth the effort! a much more cost effective way to see the Harbour and surrounds.Also includes a museum and history of the bridge.
great view. best value for money, & incredible view of the whole of Sydney & you can take your camera & own pics

Awesome views. We caught the ferry from circular quay to milsons point then walked back across the bridge. We then climbed the pylon tower and paid the fee to go up to the lookout. Wow!! Well worth it. There are amazing views from every possy. Along the rails are maps showing where everything is. Very interesting and amazing to see the conditions that the men worked in.
Good views of the harbour. Not sure you need to pay the money to get higher than the road level to get the views, but it's a cheaper option than doing the bridge climb.

Look at the views. As we are not ones for heights, we avoided the Bridge climb and went for this instead, We are so glad that we did. The views from the top are stunning. Lot of photos taken. The history part was so well done and I learnt many a thing. Spoiler alert: did you know the arc of the bridge and the pylons are not actually connected. Have a look. We had beautiful weather on the day we did this and I think that made a difference as well. You get chance to look down at the bridge climbers as well. Not crowded when we did it around 11am. Very good value for money. Would recommend.

Better value for money than doing the BridgeClimb.. Someone recommended that I did this rather than the BridgeClimb, as it is so much cheaper, and it is definitely better value for money. You do get a nice view from the top, but the pylon is not actually that much higher than the footpath across the bridge itself, so just walking acroass the bridge and looking out at the views is pretty impressive! There are some good displays/information panels on the way up if you are interested in the history of the bridge too.
Fantastic View. Nearly the same view as Habour Bridge Climb but for only $13,-. Interesting exhibition about the construction of the Harbour Bridge.
Nice Harbour Views. Good Habour views. Lots stars to go up. $13.00 to go up. After that stop at the Rocks for at The Glenmore Pub.

Great Value. What a great alternative to the bridge climb! The pylon climb offers a wealth of information about the design, construction and history of the bridge. The various levels are well laid out with information easy to read and well presented. There are many steps to be negotiated and may be difficult for people with limited mobility, however my 79 year old father managed well with frequent stops at the strategically placed seats along the way. The distraction of so much to see along the way found dad at the lookout before he realised. The view is absolutely worth the effort!

Very Sydney. A visit to the Pylon Lookout is a great, cheap alternative to the Bridgeclimb. You climb a few steps to the top, which offers 360-degree views of Sydney Harbour. There's a little souvenir shop, a display of Bridge history, and the opportunity to go outside on a walkway that circumnavigates the top of the Pylon. It is the southern end of the Bridge. The cost is very moderate: $15 for adults, and only $8 concession. It was a perfect late winter day when we visited: try to pick your time. You could combine your visit with a walk across the Bridge. A great outing.

Not much lower than the Harbour Bridge but a fraction of the cost!. Someone recommended I go up this after seeing how deterred I was after seeing the cost to climb the Harbour Bridge. In the end I went up here for $10 and was nearly as high and did the Westfield Sky Tower which is much higher with better views and still saved a packet. There's no queue for here and it's not well advertised and seems to be mainly by word of mouth.

Incredibile view of the city. If you're not willing or able to climb the Sydney Harbor Bridge itself, you must climb the bridge pylon. Only a couple hundred steps up the inside of the pylon with a museum, gift shop and theatre along the way with another historical display on the top floor. 360 degree views from the observation deck where you can take spectacular photos. Well worth the effort.
Great View. I thought it a bit pricy but the view is spectacular and much cheaper than the bridge climb. If you want a great view of the bay than this is the best for the price.

Great. Worth the climb, (lots of steps) super views. Lots of historical facts to take in along the way. View from the top is amazing and although not as high as the bridge is high enough. Panaramic vies of the harbour.
Great view from the Bridge. Nice lookout from the bridge facing the western part of the city. you could see the skyline of Sydney if you look up North from the bridge
Easy walk with a great view to offer.. A very easy walk to the point and offer great view to the harbour. Close to the bridge and rocks. Do not miss visit at night time, it is as amazing as day time.
Not a necessity. Good views once you reach the top after all the stairs. Bit expensive on the price. You have a nice view just being on the bridge, this just changes the height of your view.
do go and take pics. just by chance we ended at this point as we had nothing to do,so we decided to cross the bridge.breathtaking view.
Stunning Views. Not as popular às they Bridge walk, but still gives spectacular views of them Harbour and then city with less fuss and time needed.

"Excellent alternative to the bridge climb". For those of us not brave enough to conquer the bridge climb or for those travellers on a budget, this is an excellent alternative.For a small fee, you can get interesting facts on the bridge and its history, see the small museum as well as get a great work out as there are stairs aplenty.Once you have reached the top the views are simpy stunning and you can see all Sydney has to offer in all directions, it really is an amzing picture and the perfect spot for you to take your photographs.
Sydney Must Do - Great Value. Great way to see the view from Harbour Bridge, You get similar view to the Bridge Climb without the expense!
Wonderful view of the city. The pylon lookout allows you to have a 360 degrees view of the city and its bay and the view is simply breathtaking. Well recommended!

Great place to take photos after your bridge climb. Free admission after the bridge climb. Don't know if I would have paid for it but if you don't do the climb, an alternative to think about. Good views and markers showing you where the sights are.

Great views, good works out and well priced . I really enjoyed this activity and have recommended it to all my friends. Especially as an alternative to doing the bridge climb! A lot of stairs and a interactive information throughout!
Great views. Excellent view of harbor bridge and opera house. It's not expensive and the experience was amazing. Views are great.

The Thai President invited me to attend Business Lunch !. The Cumberland Street is very exclusive area , because they have a five star hotel there . The have changed name for many times already . Original is the Japanese Hotel and now it is still a Five Star Hotel. Shangri -La Hotel . After the hotel top floor , dinning room and the Bar which you can see the best views of the Opera House , Sydney Harbour Bridge , and over look North Sydney . We have attended all the Australian Government Functions there or Foreign diplomat function there . Because they have good security systems and catering good food and large function room ! Most of the Foreign Diplomat love stay in this hotel .

Far cheaper than the Bridgeclimb. This is an excellent alternative to the Bridgeclimb, which although absolutely an amazing experience, can be VERY pricey indeed, and subject to inclement weather. And probably not that suitable for those with a fear of heights.As an alternative, however, the Pylon Lookout offers sensational views over the harbour and the city - from ALL directions, which unimpeded, spectacular views. Be warned that there are QUITE a few flights of stairs to climb, so it's not for everyone, and there's no wheelchair access.But for under $20, you get a look at the history of the bridge, an insight in to how it was built, and once again, SPECTACULAR views. And for those with a fear of heights - don't worry! The outdoor viewing area has a VERY high wall, and protective glass shields. It's almost impossible to even LEAN over the thick wall to look down, and even if you could, it's slightly stepped.Fantastic few hours!

Beautiful structure. We visited the lookout on a superb winters day in August (winter in Sydney is as warm as our summer in the UK!) Our two young children enjoyed the climb up to the viewing area and the view of the Sydney skyline and harbour is undeniably breathtaking. However, equally breathtaking is the intricate latticework of the bridge itself. This iconic structure is majestic and beautiful; the designers, engineers and construction workers did an amazing job. There are some fascinating displays on the different floors and a short film gives an overview of the history of the bridge. We got off the train at Milsons Point and walked across the bridge to get to the pylon - a lovely short walk in itself. A must do when visiting Sydney.
Great Photo Op. Awesome view of the city! It is pretty high up and you need to climb it. The only reason it doesn't get a 5 is due to the fee to access the Pylon.

AMAZING VIEW!!!!!. What an 360 degrees view of Sydney. They have a museum type section, gift store and a small slide show of photos. Then at the very top you have the view. So glad that I went there. However before attending make sure you read the directions on their website to avoid going the wrong way, don't just Google the address. Also the entry to the Pylon does feel as though you might be going the wrong way, but your not.
Do it. It's worth it. Great views From here at a very low cost. As good as the bridge climb reallyLoved it, it has all the history of the building of it. Pictures etc.Do it, it's worth it.
Great views an cheap entry. Only a few dollars ($5) to enter and it has some of the best views you are ever going to get in Sydney. Looks straight down Sydney harbour - just magical.

Astonishing views. We were here on a perfect sunny morning with Grayline city tour of Sydney. The views of harbour bridge, Opera House and the riverfront are amazing. The benches provided here are comfortable and seat upto 4 persons comfortably. The place is clean and not quite crowded .

Not cheap, but it's worth it. It might not be the cheapest thing to do but it's worth its value, especially at dawn or sunset. You'll be able to take magnificent photos of the Harbour Bridge, the Opera House and the city center.
Great view. Great way to get a look out view of the harbour and close up view of the bridge. Worth the $13 for tickets.

$13 = great value. You could go on the more expensive bridge climb experience or do what we did; $13 entry to the south east pylon, spectacular view of Sydney Harbour and the iconic Opera House with a museum that tells the story of the construction of the bridge. Great value and a short walk from the Rocks

A different perspective. After spending time in the waterfront seeing the city skyline or riding the ferries, or even seeing the city from the harbour next to the opera house the pylon lookout gives you a different perspective of the city as you are beyond these points and before this city bank itself.

Fantastic alternative to the Bridge Climb. We found this by chance, and it was the highlight of our trip! We thought this was a fantastic alternative to the overpriced Bridge Climb. It was a bit of an adventure to find the pylon, but that was part of the fun. We arrived in mid afternoon, and while there was a steady stream of visitors, you could hardly say it was crowded. Views were spectacular, and the glass panelling provided extra information on the surrounding areas. Great bits of history on the bridge were also dotted around, and provided a great educational excuse to take a breather after climbing all those stairs. Bathrooms available on the gift store level, something I was not expecting. Unlike the Bridge Climb, you can stay at the top as long as you want. Don't forget to wave at those doing the Bridge Climb!
Great Views of Sydney Harbour. Climbing up the lookout in The Rocks area offers magnificent views of Sydney Harbour. While you're at it, climb up the Harbour Bridge!

Certainly Worth The Money - Views are Fantastic. The views in the day are very nice especially if you have the weather, not so good on overcast. But I think the nights would be fantastic. Not so good if you cant handle heights and climbing steps. Other than that certainly well worth the trip up.

Fantastic location, best view. I always bring oversea visitors to the Pylon lookout. It is a great view, not expensive and has the history of the bridge. We warned there are lots of steps to climb but it is worth it. At the top there is the original plate along the top of the wall that has all the landmarks marked.

Top of the Pylon View of Sydney Harbor. We walked up through The Rocks area at the waterfront of Sydney Harbor to the Pylon of the Sydney Bridge to watch the sunset. In the cool evening air it was a refreshing walk and we were rewarded by wonderful views.

The Best Bargain I Have Ever Accounted in all my World Travels!. The best bargain I have ever accounted in all my world travels! The view is spectacular and you don't have to be the daredevil type who climbs on top Sydney's "Iron Lung."

Bridge climb without the climb. We had a hard time finding this when walking up from the Rocks but are so glad we persevered. The Harbour Bridge Climb is so popular but some of us are not meant for that. This is where the Pylon Lookout can be of assistance - it will take you approximately to the inner arch of the bridge without the climbing aspect. Yes, there are lots of stairs, some 200+ if you are counting, but in my opinion, it's worth it. The views are amazing and the sense of accomplishment is enough to feed that inner glow of warmth. The cost is insignificant - AU$13 as of July 2015. In my view, that's a good price for what you get!
A hidden treasure. This little advertised secret is an excellent place to view the opera house and harbour out to the heads. Also has interesting history of the building of the bridge.

Good views, easy to climb and look around, it covers the main sights. Good area - if you have a fear of heights this is ok (unlike the Bridge climb). The views are superb, you can see all around so well worth a visit.

Great value for tourists on a budget. As I mentioned in my review of the Harbour Bridge, the Bridge Climb is quite pricey. If you're on a budget I would recommend making a stop at the Pylon lookout. While it may not be as thrilling as the Bridge Climb, the lookout still provides amazing 360 degree views of the city, and only costs around $13.

Great Views. Didn't have time to do the "over the top" walk, so this was a great substitute, although no reason why you shouldn't do both. Great views of both sides of the Harbour Bridge.....the view west clearly doesn't include the Opera House, but it's still very dramatic.

The best view in Sydney!!. Kinda hard to find the stairs heading up from in the Rocks, and another set of steps when you get to the bridge itself, but the view from the top is amazing. Sure it has a bit of a price tag, to get up, but the displays inside are quite interesting as well as talking about the history of the bridge, size and what was all involved going into the making of the bridge. The 360' view though is the real highlight!! The whole harbour lies at your feet.

A definite must-see. This was a really worthwhile visit. I think that the entrance fee is a bit high but combine this with a walk across the Harbour Bridge in either direction and it's a morning well spent.

second visit. I went up the pylon last year and loved it so much I went again this year. Its a bit of a climb, but the steps are inside and there are resting places. well worth it. You can stay up there as long as you want with great views of the harbour and further afield.

Not really worth it. Great views over Sydney but it's debatable whether it's worth $13 when the (free) views from the bridge are not that much different. I guess the bonus here is learning about the bridge's construction and having an unobstructed 360-degree view, but in terms of the kind of photos you can get there's not a massive difference. The attitude of the lady on the ticket desk was also disgusting.
Great view, interesting. The pylon has a great views and like others say, compared to more expensive options seems reasonable.

Fantastic views at a realistic price. A short walk from The Rocks in Sydney takes you up the historic Argyle Cut steps and onto the Sydney Harbour Bridge walkway. In five minutes, you'll arrive at the South Eastern Pylon. For a measly $13 (adult) you then ascend another 200 stairs and emerge at what can only be described as amongst the best vantage points Sydney has to offer!Seriously, on a clear day you can see every part of Sydney, it's shimmering Harbour and beyond from this vantage point.The interpretive historical display in several areas during your climb is well worth seeing.

Great View. If you don't feel like spending a ton of money climbing the Sydney Harbor Bridge, but want a good view of the Opera House, the harbor, and the city, this is the place to visit! $13 AUD gets you up & close with the bridge, and you get to visit the museum inside the Pylon Lookout.

Great views of Sydney Harbour. We did this as an alternative to the bridge climb ($200-300 and you can't bring your camera?! Crazy). It may not be as high a vantage point as the bridge climb, but you get beautiful unobstructed views of Sydney harbour and you can photograph BOTH the opera house and the bridge in the same panorama (since the pylon is on the side of one end of the bridge). Can't do that from the top of the bridge!As others have commented, it is a little difficult to find-- the entrance is on the pedestrian walkway part of the bridge which you access from Cumberland St. Ask any of the security officers on the bridge how to get to the pylon lookout and they'll point you in the right direction.
Better value than the Bridge Climb. You can take your own photos and stay as long as you like Great views Great place to take guest to Sydney as you can take the time to explain the sites to them
better value than bridge climb. only $13 and amazing views. interesting information points as you climb the stairs about how the bridge was made.

Wonderful View!. My husband and I stumbled on this opportunity while walking across the bridge. It is not a bad walk and there is a lot to read about explaining the history of the bridge which makes it interesting. There is a great view of the harbor and it is only about $14 dollars per person! Definitely worth it!

Best way to see the Harbor. We found this to be an excellent way to see the harbor and a great alternative to the bridge climb. Much less expensive and you can take your camera! Be sure to check out the website and know where to go before you start out. If you just walk to the bottom of the pylon, you will not be in the right place. The steps are many but not intimidating with lots of interesting things to stop and see along the way.

A bit tricky to find but worth it. It's a 10 minute walk from the rocks (as if you're crossing the bridge) and we found this harder work than the steps once we were there. The views were great and it was not busy meaning it was easy to get photos of all angles. Also enjoyed the history displays. Definitely recommended, and good value.

Worth the walk.. Simple walk up from The Rocks and along to South East Pylon. Good information in the pylon about the history of the bridge and it's building. Fantastic view of the harbour and bridge. Great value for money.

Just Beautiful. Perfect of picnic with friends and families! Visited multiple times by myself or taking friends and family members who are visiting. They all loved this place and would not want to leave because it is just beautiful and relaxing.
Pylon climb. Do this walk. There Re some stairs but the view is great and well worth it. There is interesting information on the way.

Worthwhile if you don't do the bridge climb. We used our free ticket from the bridge climb to visit here a day or so later. It was a great view but perhaps not as good as the climb. Mind you its $300 Aus dollars cheaper. You get a good bit of history of the bridge and I would recommend it particularly if you don't do the climb.

Yorkshireman's view. This is what I would describe as the Yorkshireman's view....because it's a bargain! While you can pay $250 and climb the bridge, for those on a budget this is the perfect alternative.You still get great views, but for $10 and you also get to take your own pictures and not have to pay for them! There is also an interesting exhibit on how the bridge was built and again this is a must do whilst in Sydney in my humble opinion.

Cheaper alternative to bridge climb. I did the bridge climb and you can't compare it to the pylon lookout but if you don't want to spend the money on the climb, the pylon lookout is certainly a very good alternative. You can take some really beautiful photographs of the opera house, bridge etc from here.We did find it a bit difficult to find the entrance. If you do the bridge climb, the pylon lookout is included in the price.
Photo opportunity. If you climb the bridge you will get free access to this building. Excellent place to take some panoramic photos of the area.
Fantastic view, not to be missed!. I was there about an hour before sunset and the view was spectacular. I didn't have time to do the Bridge Walk, but was not at all disappointed to do this instead.

Great view. A short walk across the Bridge from the CBD. Although I have been to Sydney lots I never knew the Pylon Lookout existed. Now I would highly recommend the kids loved it- great views over Sydney, the Opera House and Harbour and down onto the Bridge. You pay but only a small price for the view. So if you don't want to do the climb this is the next best thing

Really interesting. The only problem with this attraction is the steps. I didn't count them but there are heaps. Once you get there it is very interesting to read about the construction of the bridge. I was born in Sydney and have seen this bridge often so it was nice to find out the history of it's building.

A must go if you are in sydney. It is a great place when bridge climbing seems to be too expensive. this pylon, you could see pretty much like in the bridge climbing.it cost you so less compare to bridge climbing. if you have a budget, go for bridge climbing otherwise, here could be a great place too! good for photography as well

Pylon Lookout at Sydney Harbour Bridge. Cool spot to view the Opera house and Sydney Harbour. You have to walk out onto the Sydney Harbour Bridge because it is half way across the bridge. But, it is fun to say you've done the walk.

Excellent views. A great alternative to the Bridge Climb. We had done the bridge climb and really enjoyed it but it is expensive so it's great that you can do this for $13. The views are great and there's lots of interesting information. We got the tickets for this for free with the bridge climb so it was nice to do both but if you really wanted to do the bridge climb and were put off by the price then do this it's great!
Beautiful view. A really great little experience and a beautiful view of Sydney. You get to learn about the history of the bridge and defiantly worth a visit while you're in the city.

Superb. Thought Auckland was great - and it is - but Sydney up on another level. Must be close to the most beautiful city in the world on a cold winter morning with clear skies and a magnificent view of sea, buildings and nature. Costs a bit but absolutely worth the money.
Awesome views of the Bridge and Opera House!. A great way to get a picture of the Bridge and Opera House. You have to just walk up 200 stairs instead of 1000+ at the Bridge Climb.

Fun but quite expensive. Good views across the harbour, but a bit expensive probably a $20 family ticket would be about the right price. The exhibitions are very old school with no interactive components that are feature of most modern museums

Nice views!. It has very nice views, but the view from the Bridge Climb is better. The Bridge Climb is much more expensive (and includes a free visit to the Pylon lookout). This is a cheaper alternative to the Bridge Climb.

Nice View. We walked to the foot of the pylon and looked for the entrance, but the entrance was not there, but on the bridge. Also, there was no lift in the pylon, so we had to walk up the satires. That was a GREAT exercise. However, the view of the Sydney Harbour was fine and satisfactory.
try it. i tried it as i was on a budget and can not afford to do the bridge climb. It was less expensive and i had a good view of the beautiful city
the photo of us. Pylon on Sydney Harbour Bridge interesting building and showing history and photos of the building of the bridge .on completion a souvenir photo

brilliant views of sydney harbour. just 200 easy steps to the top of the south pylon with amazing views over the city and harbour. A 360 degrees view as you walk around the viewing area that looks to be about 2/3 reds of the height of the top of the bridge. Very cheap for brilliant views - about $13 adult.
Good value and a great view!. No need to do the Bridge Climb as the pylon lookout gives you a very good view of the harbour, Opera House and the bridge. Way cheaper as well!

outstanding view top 5 must do whilst in Sydney. This is one of Sydney's best kept secrets. I just love this spot. It is one of the top 5 things to do whilst in Sydney and is one of the cheapest too. The view is breathtaking. Every time I visit Sydney I try to do this.
Bridge walker. Surprised to find this, a little gem on the bridge. Loved the story it tells and the pictures and information are well worth the visit.
Glorious Views. We went up the pylon lookout on a sunny Autumn day and the 360 views were spectacular....we took so many photos!!

Wow what a view. We got given a free pass to this after completing the bridge climb the night before and wow was it worth it. This gives you 360 degree views of the harbour and you can take your camera this time. It well worth the effort don't miss out
VIEWS!!. Outstanding value. Views almost as good as the Bridge climb. Plus the benefit of continuing the walk across the bridge, where a suburban train station can be located on either end.

Pylon Lookout. If you do the Sydney Bridge Climb you get a free pass to this museum for free to use within the next 30 days. We waited for a beautiful day and were not disappointed. This has amazing, picture perfect views of the Opera House, the climbers on the bridge, Luna Park...

Decent view of Sydney.... So it costs $13 to climb the pylon....a fraction of the cost for the bridge climb and just as good of a view!
Brilliant views over the harbour and city skyline!

A nice climb. I did this after climbing the harbor bridge. It is a nice walk, and you can get your own photos of the view. There are 200steps, but not too bad. It was peaceful and quiet. I had a voucher to get in from the bridge climb; otherwise it costs $13

A highlight of my trip to Sydney. I hadn't read about this place, I just happened upon it when walking along the Bridge and I'm so glad I did as it was really good. For a small entrance fee you can climb up to the top of one of the towers at either end of the Harbour Bridge where there is a small museum explaining the building of the bridge and then you can go outside and - wow - the view from the top is brilliant! I didn't feel that by not climbing the bridge itself I had missed out because I went up the Pylon lookout. I could see the people climbing the bridge in front of me and had a brilliant 360 degree view all around. So worth doing!! At the end of the little museum, before you descend the tower there is a short video to watch which shows the history of the bridge and is really moving.

Good lookout. I didn't plan for a bridge climb and a local taxi driver recommended me to go here to take a good look of the harbor. I went there at the evening and the view was excellent. Good for photos and getting amazed.

Great view and much cheaper than the Bridge climb.. The price tag for the Bridge climb turned us off it so we did the Pylon lookout. Great vistas from the top and you can almost reach out and touch the climbers on the coathanger. On the way up there are displays and info about the bridge and the scissors that were used to cut the ribbon on opening day (or are they a replica, I can't remember). Highly recommended.

a great view of the harbor if you don't want to pay the exorbitant price to climb over the harbor bridge. The excitement is not the same as climbing on top of the bridge. I did both, but I admit that you can enjoy a great view just from the pylones.

Breath Taking Views. At $13 per person you will not be sorry once you've climbed the steps to get to the top. The views of the Darbour Harbour and surroundings are worth it, this is an excellent way to be as close to climbing the bridge. As you can get without doing the bridge climb. There is a gift shop and a display of the bridge being built and even a short movie to watch it very educational .
Great view. It was free and it was really a great spot to take photos from. We felt safe and secure and enjoyed the experience.
Unbelievable views!. Nice alternative to the expensive bridge climb. You get am incredible view of the Opera House, Harbour and Harbour Bridge from a different angle.

Free with Bridge climb. It took us a while to work out how to get here and walk across the bridge - there is also 200 stairs and no lifts.
But it is a great photo opportunity and there is even a little video you can watch of all the men making the bridge

Amazing Views. This is a great attraction and a must if you're visiting Sydney. For those who are not quite adventurous enough to do the Bridge Climb this has a great vantage point for the many views and has a great view of those doing the climb.

You get a great view...good bang for your buck!. If you wanted to climb the bridge (we did) but didn't have the time or the money, the view from the pylon is almost as good. You can take your own pictures and spend as much time as you would like. As you climb the stairs up, you can take breaks at the little museum displays on the way. If you have the time and the money, the bridge climb is a much cooler experience, though.

Absolutely Brilliant!. I'm so pleased I found this on Tripadvisor, what a fantastic experience! My son really wanted to do the Bridge Climb for his 11th Birthday, but it was just too expensive, then I came across this when looking through Tripadvisor and the reviews were so good, we just had to do it and so glad we did, the views were amazing, for a fraction of the price of the Bridge Climb and you can take your own photos!We were also lucky enough to be there in time for Vivid, which started soon after we came down from the lookout, so we had a fantastic view of it from the bridge!Definitely a "must do" when you visit Sydney!
Cheap. Good as the Bridge walk but so much cheaper.lot's of interesting information and photo's.Don't forget to check out the Glenmore's roof top bar!

Great inexpensive view. Only 100 stairs instead of the harbour bridge climb, the pylon affords great views of the harbour on a great day and tells the story of the bridge's construction on the way up. Awesome if you are afraid of heights as there is lots of security for you - a big high wall around the top of the pylon, solid floor etc.
Alternative to the bridge climb. For a cheaper price, one can get the same view as climbing the harbour bridge. You get a bird's eye view of the harbour and the Sydney skylines.
Great views. Went here after doing a bridge climb and the views are great, seeing the bridge from a different angle and looking over the harbour well worth the effort of climbing the steps!

VIEWS WELL WORTH THE VISIT. Although maps were inaccurate and it was hard to find the stairs, the views itself make the trip worthwhile. The stairs up to Cumberland Street are located on the right side just at the beginning of the Argyle Street Bridge. Once on Cumberland Street the stairs to the Bridge Walk are almost diagonally opposite across the street. The walk to the pylon is enjoyable and once at the pylon go up the stairs to the first level, cost I think was $15.00, second level has a little store and toilets and then climb to the top. Views are great and on each level there is a mini museum showing the building of the bridge. There is even a theatre. All in all a great visit. Be prepared to walk and lots and lots of stairs (200 in all they say).

Great view!. For $13 you can go to the top of the Pylon for some pretty great views of the Sydney harbour. After climbing the bridge we had two vouchers to get to the top for free. Before heading up be sure to read up on the history of the bridge. You'll have a better appreciation for it.

Amazing view of Sydney. The Pylon Lookout is located on the pedestrian path on Sydney Harbour Bridge. In order to access the Pylon lookout, you need to climb the Bridge stairs on Cumberland Street. You need to climb 200 steps stairs in order to reach Pylon lookout which is 87 metres above the sea level. Once you reached at the top, you will be rewarded with spectacular view of Sydney.
