Great views. This was a great find - had heard about the bridge climb before heading to Sydney but didn't know this option existed. It was a fantastic way of seeing both the bridge and the amazing views without breaking the bank (and there's a YHA discount too if you're a member). Spent a good while at the top just taking in the sights and, most of the time, we were the only ones there! The information on the way up and down on the history of the bridge construction was fascinating - even kept the children interested! Follow this up by walking over the bridge (equally amazing views) to Kirribilli for lunch where we found a great fish and chip restaurant!

Lovely views. As I don't like heights or lots of steps this was a great visit to make. Although there are steps there are things to read or look at every so often which gives you a chance to take a breather! I found it very interesting and the views from the top are spectacular.
Good alternative for not climbing. When you're not able to climb the bridge this is a good alternative, we visited the pylon with climbers and non-climbers and were able to share the experience!
Great Views. Great harbour views at a fraction of the price of the Bridgeclimb, so great for families. There is also just enough history for interest. The only drawback is if you can't handle steps.

Excellent value. This is an excellent way to see the city at a fraction of the cost of the bridge climb. 200 stairs with a few places to stop and a water fountain. The views are outstanding although it is quite a small viewing area at the top. Very good value at just $13. Many thanks to Bridgeclimb staff for complimentary tickets as my daughter was too young to climb the bridge with me- very nice gesture

What a great find. I never knew this existed but a google search found this gem of a tourist thing to do in Sydney. The Bridge climb is $258 this was $13 and we climbed 200 steps up the Pylon with historical info all the way up to the top where we had great views of the harbour!!

Nice compliment to the bridge climb. We got the free passes as part of the climb and decided to check it out after we returned to Sydney from Cairns. The views are pretty good and you can linger as long as you want on the top viewing deck which offers great panoramic views around the harbor. The museum gives great background history of the bridge and offers more details than our bridge climb guide (or maybe we just got distracted by the awesome views during the climb?). The climb is an adventure in itself with higher views of the harbor and closed-up looks of the bridge. But this is a great compliment to the climb and a more relaxed way to get the views.
Great views across the rooftops of Glasgow. Great views across the bridge and over the opera house. We got free entry with the bridge climb ticket as they are run by the same company.

Cheaper than the bridge climb.. A great alternative to the bridge climb and a fraction of the cost! AND you can take your own camera which you can not do on the bridge climb. There are lots of stairs so it may not be suitable for those less agile. However if you take your time it's doable .there are very interesting photos and history of the bridge.

Fantastic!. Before we went to Sydney a friend told me to do this instead of the Bridge climb as it is so much cheaper and the views just as spectacular. I was so glad I took her advice! Only $13 entry fee, and they also kindly gave my daughter a student discount of $5 as she had her UK Uni card with her ( I was impressed with this as lots of other places we visited in Australia refused to take a 'foreign' Uni card). The views of Sydney were amazing and you could spend as long as you liked at the top. We then walked across the bridge (twice) and there were some great views of the Opera House from the other side. Loved the whole thing!

excellent. For $13.00 per adult (not sure of children's cost) money well spent. A nice climb up stairs to the top with spectacular views of the bridge and Sydney itself. we spent probably an hour at the top just wondering around, just watching the ever changing scenery below and in the harbor itself. It provides a great deal of history on the bridge how it was built and designed etc. Easy walk from the Rocks well sign posted. This is our second visit and we will do it again the next time we are in Sydney. this is a cheaper way of seeing the bridge, but just as spectacular.
Panorama view of Sydney Harbour. Totally well worth a visit. Only $13 and you have a very informative visit about the Harbour Bridge's history as well as an amazing 360 degree view of Sydney Harbour.

Budget alternative to bridge climb. You will come across the entrance to this small lookout and museum as you walk across the bridge eastern pedestrian walkway. It is a cheap entry price. I think $10 last time. There is a small museum and a theatre with short film about the history and building of the bridge. Then there is the outdoor lookout on top. It is a sensational view of the city and harbour and the bridge itself. There is high walls so not scary for height effected people.

Very informative. No need to do the bridge climb when you can save money and come here. Lots and lots of information about the bridges history. People worked very hard to build this amazing bridge and some fell to their deaths. Fantastic view.

Well worth the visit!. $13 per adult to view the exhibition and climb to the top of the pylon. A great alternative to the $200-$350 cost of the bridge climb. Finish off by walking across the bridge then catching a train (or ferry) from Milson's Point back to Circular Quay.

A perfect, price-sensitive alternative to the Bridge Climb. I really love bridges. And I really wanted to do the Bridge Climb. But with all the added expenses of having a chronically ravenous teenager traveling with me, I realized we'd have to give up other things like taking in a show at the Opera House if we spent the $500 on two tickets for a climb. So, we headed up the pylons instead. The two tickets were less than a tenth of the price. We were self guided, on our own timeline, and had amazing views in literally every direction. Heck, even if you can afford the climb, add this to your day: it's an absolute gem.
Awesome Views. One of the MUST DO things in Sydney. Unbelievable views and a great museum as you make your way to the top.

Great little spot to visit!. My family loved going up the Pylon for a spectacular view of the area! It also provided a great deal of history and information about how the bridge was built and how they came up with the final design. Definitely a must visit if you're passing-by!
Easy. I paid about $14 and climbed the stairs to the top of one of the pylons, which was considerably cheaper than the bridge climb.

Brilliant. If you like the bridge at all, you will love this. I wish there had been more accounts from people at the time it was built but there was plenty of information about the building of the bridge. The view from the top is great. 13 dollars well spent.

Inexpensive option to BridgeClimb. Great view and history lesson. Enter from The Bridge pedestrian walkway from Circular Quay or The Rocks. $13 for adults and $6.50 for kids.... Probably the most under rated thing to do in Sydney, Very worthwhile.

Easily accessed. Easily reached via the pedestrian route from The Rocks and Argyle Street. So you can combine a walk across Sydney Bridge with a visit to the Rocks, though there's lots of walking to be done.

nice views and less expensive and less scary than the bridge climb. If you just want some good views and some history of the bridge, this is your ticket. For $15 you can climb up the pylon (inside on stairs).

Worth for money. Compare to some of the harbor bridge activities, the price is reasonable and the view is excellent. You can have few good photos and enjoyed the view and same time some education about the history and building of the Bridge

Fun, yet informative. This was possibly the best thing I did in Australia. The tour guide was amazing, telling us about the history of the bridge as well as where the stars where staying recently. Once we arrived at the top of the bridge there was an amazing view, as well as a photo opportunity which you get for free. For anyone who is scared of heights, there is no need to worry as you are securely hooked on throughout the tour. Definitely an experience worth doing!
Bird Eye View of Sydney Opera House. What else can I say ... bird-eye view of Sydney Opera House. Awesome view !!! A must view.Nice walk on Harbour Bridge as well ... I love it !

understand the bridge and get a great view. I've not done the bridge climb but for a fraction of the cost you get fabulous views of all parts of Sydney and the harbour and with the added bonus you can take pictures and spend as much time as you want. You also get to find out about the bridge construction.

Better value than the bridge climb for the same views. If you are thinking about doing the bridge walk, but are disappointed that they won't let you take your camera, consider doing this instead. No, it's not as glamorous. But the views are nearly identical. There places you can rest of the stairs seem intimidating, you can capture the views you want on your camera, you can stay as long as you want, and the price is a lot less. It all just depends on what is most important to you. For me, the Pylon was the way to go.

Great views, inexpensive. You don't need to do the Bridge Climb to get great views of Sydney Harbour. Instead, head up to the Pylon Lookout. There are fantastic views from up here, well worth the price.Note, there are stairs.

Can't imagine NOT doing this while in Sydney!. I really can't imagine a trip to Sydney without going to the Pylon lookout. It's affordable, provides beautiful views of the harbour, provides an awesome history of the bridge (I may be biased as a bridge engineer...) and did I mention it's NOT over $200? I see no reason to skip this.

Great views and workout!!!. Opted for this instead of the bridge climb due to time restrictions and cost. Was not disappointed. Walked from the ferry terminal and got a great workout by the time I reached the top. Saw cruise ships in all directions, and as it was a beautiful summer day, lots of boats on the Harbour as well. Would recommend for all ages - you can take as many rests as you like on the way up and down.

Million dollar views at bargain basement price. If you can't afford to climb the Bridge, come here instead. The view is almost as good, for a fraction of the price, and you can take as many shots with your own camera as you want.

Vantage point for photography. The cost of the bridge climb was a little out of our reach, and we didn't have the time to do it too, so we settle for the Pylon Lookout. We weren't disappointed. Not only were we treated to a great history lesson, but the pylon was an excellent place for photography of the Bridge itself, traffic and the various modes of transport on the Bradfield Highway, Circular Quay, Opera House, the harbour, etc. We could see groups of bridge climbers doing their stuff. I have no hesitations recommending this attraction for any first-time visitor to Sydney.

Great Views, Interesting History. The Pylon Lookout is a great budget alternative to the bridge climb, with the added attraction of interesting historical displays and facts about the building of the bridge. Once at the top you’re almost at the same height as the bridge climb with sweeping panoramic views of the city and harbour so make sure you have a camera.One word of warning: the walk from Circular Quay was longer than we expected and included several more flights of stairs. Older adults or youngsters might find this a bit much, especially when combined with the 200 stairs up the pylon, plus the walk back.

Great alternative to the bridge climb. The harbour bridge climb in Sydney is touted as one of the unmissable things to do when one is visiting the city. However, this is an extremely expensive affair and will create a significant dent in the budget of any traveller.A great $12 alternative is to climb the pylon lookout at the harbour bridge, It takes you to an elevation that is 75% of the way up the bridge and costs you a fraction of the bridge climb.If you dont mind climbing a lot of stairs (you would need to do that on the bridge climb too) and are on a budget, this is a great workaround to doing the actual climb.

Spectacular views with interesting history. The view and history of the museum was fantastic. A great spot to watch the bridge climbers. We did not know you could even go up the pylon for this view so it was a wonderful surprise.

Cheaper than the Bridge Climb.... ... and maybe more worth the price of it ? Had a great view over Sydney, learned some about its history and great monument to be in. I like to think of it as a reward, after the effort of finding it and climbing all the stairs.

Nice views without the vertigo. Not quite as high up as the bridge walk, but still had very nice views. Also, a lot less expensive than the bridge climb. We went up on a cloudy, windy day, yet still enjoyed the views. Highly recommend it.

Fantastic Views. For about $15 you can climb the pylon stairs for an even higher perspective of Sydney Harbor and take photos like the ones you see in magazines. There are static displays that tell the history of the bridge.

Amazing views. Only found the Pylon lookout by walking across the bridge. For a small fee, and climbing close to 200 stairs, you get some wonderful views of Sydney and the harbour. I think it adds to the views that you get from the Tower. There is a small gift shop halfway up the climb inside the pylon which serves as a pitstop. Once at the top, the views are brilliant! Well worth climbing the stairs for!

Beats Sydney Tower. For a third of the price of the mostly unpleasant Sydney Tower experience, and providing you can climb a few flights of stairs, you can visit and climb one of the Harbour Bridge Pylons - the history of the bridge is simply and thoughtfully set out with a number of interesting displays and the views are stunning - you are hovering right over the Harbour, getting a stunning view of the Bridge and Bennelong Point and you're in the open air. Highly recommended.

View to die for!!!!!. I took my daughters 5 and 12 to walk up the Pylon I didn't even know you could do this before last week we loved it the walk up was easy the view from the top is truly amazing. They have really interesting facts about the bridge they you can look at as your walking to the top.There is a small fee to do this but it is totally worth it.After you walk back down you can watch a movie about the bridge which the girls really liked.

great views. If you cant afford the bridge climb this is a great way to see Sydney harbour up high. The stairs almost killed us but there is chairs to rest at on the way up and the view is worth it. the history of the bridge is very interesting. If you havent done the bridge climb before this you will want to do it after visiting the lookout. we found this harder to get up than the bridge climb
Cheaper than Bridge Climb. Start at Circular Quay and walk thru the Rocks, then part way across the Bridge to this museum with spectacular views. There is an entry fee but it is well worth it

Perfect Picture Taking Location. Although there's several steps to climb (and I went up this lookout right after climbing the Harbour Bridge), it's perfect to go here and take pictures over Circular Quay and the Opera House as the sun sets!
Great views. Great view & easy walk for those not up to climbing to the top. We didn't have time for the big climb but found this lookout sufficient !!

Try walking across the bridge. If you don't want to pay, and if you want different views of the bridge, then please consider walking straight across the bridge. Lots of gorgeous scenery on the bridge, and at the bridge landing area across the harbour. Also, you can visit the area around Luna Park.
Great view at great price. Next best thing to bridge climb but fraction of the cost. You are 3/4 of the way up at the top of the pylon
Worth the money. I wasn't sure if it was worth going in but it was just for the views alone. Great 360 views of the harbour from up high. One of my highlights of the trip to Sydney.

A little known place to a great view of the Harbour Bridge. In my opinion, you cannot really enjoyed the view of the harbour bridge if you are on it. The Pylon Lookout cost A$13 which is only a fraction of the cost of the harbour bridge but of course the experience would be very different. We thoroughly enjoyed the up close view of the Sydney Harbour bridge and the beautiful harbour and Opera House in the background. Awesome!For more info, do visit www.misschocoholic.com
Alternative to Bridge Walk. If you don't have the stomach for the full climb, go up 200 steps in this tower to view your companion's ordeal !
great do this a long walk worth it in the end. had a great view across the harbour walk from Cahill pass then walk about 1 hour down to the other side of the Bridge about $25.00 pre person

Sydney Harbour Bridge Pylon Lookout. This is a little known attraction in Sydney (probably not for long after this review)! The south east pylon of the bridge has a lookout which can be reached by climbing 200 steps from the road level of the bridge. On the way up there are 3 levels of exhibits detailing the construction. Admission price is very reasonable and a senior's discount is also available. The lookout is at 87 metres above sea level and provides uninterrupted views of Sydney Opera House and Circular Quay. The pylon can be reached by foot from either The Rocks or the northern end of the bridge. The walk from the northern end of the bridge also gives good views of the harbour. Unfortunately the lookout closes at 5pm, so it is only in mid winter you can see the sunset. It is not open until 10am, so sunrise is not possible.

Best value view of the Harbour. If you want to avoid the ever increasing price of the Bridge Climb, the best value view is from the SE Pylon of the Bridge. You don't get quite as high but it is a terrific view and a lot quicker and cheaper!
Magical views of Sydney Harbour. Enjoy views of the most beautiful harbour in the world from the Pylon lookout. Great vintage point for photo enthuthiasts

Check out the view!. Beautiful clear sunny Winter afternoon, we walked from The Rocks to the Pylon Lookout (20 Mins) Take your camera, the views are spectacular. Lots of stairs so could be tricky if you have a stroller.

Nice view. Step back into the history of the Sydney Harbour Bridge
Its beginnings, its planning and construction, its vision.
I loved the place. Must see in Sydney.

Great View. Do this if you can't climb the bridge, you will not regret. With a minimal fee, one can get 360 degree view of Sydney. We took some very nice pics from here. This is as near as you can get to the bridge without climbing it. Make sure you go on a clear day. Very nice indeed.

Great 360 Degrees View. The walk from The Rocks to the Pylon Lookout took about 15 to 20 minutes.Museum and facts about the bridge in the Pylon Lookout were very interesting and there is a total of 200 steps to climb to reach the top of the Lookout, very manageable. The 360 degrees view from the top was beautiful.I find the AUD13 admission fee very worthwhile and I enjoyed the walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge too.
Great View. Well worth the walk to get there, Could use a better mappingsystem. If you do not to the Bridge climb, almost the same view without the thrill of being out over the water.

Worth the admission, great views and history. For those not adventurous enough to do the Bridge Walk, the Pylon lookout is a great substitute for getting up close and personal with the bridge and learning about the history of its construction. Lots of stairs to climb but shouldn't be an issue for most.
Interesting fun and a great view. Has great video on the making of the bridge cheap tickets and that amazing view been so many times never can get enough

Well worth climbing up. For $13 AUD you get some nice displays and good info, then you climb the stairs to the 89m deck where you get cracking views of Sydney and info to tell you what you are looking at. When I was there you could see the Blue Mountains at 60km. You get most of the view of the actual bridge climb, without most of the cost and 3 hours of walking up a set of stairs attached to a guide wire.

Good cheap alternative to BridgeClimb - harbour views. A good alternative to BridgeClimb if unable to afford the prices. Lots of stairs to climb and an interesting archive/display covering the building of the Sydney Harbour Bridge on your way to the external viewing area. Obviously doesn't offer views as good as BridgeClimb, but for the price, they are pretty good. Worth doing if some of your friends are on BridgeClimb as you can see each other part-way up! Good photos

Excellent views and surprisingly interesting museum. We thought the climb was way too expensive to be worth considering, and seeing it from the top of the Pylon it didn't even look that fun to be honest. Visiting the Pylon Lookout was well worth the time though! You get to see some beatiful 360 views of Sydney and while going up you go through a museum over how the bridge was built, which was much more interesting than I had expected!

Great Views & Educational. Was worth the climb for the wonderful views of the harbour. Good opportunity for photography, learning about the history of the Harbour Bridge and all at a very economical price. A fun and rewarding experience and cost friendly ! Hghly recommended.
Wow... Sydney's hidden gem.. If you do nothing else in Sydney, make sure you at least put this on your must do list. The view is well worth it..

Great views. Nice way of getting a better view than from the deck of the bridge. There's some displays of the Bridge's history on the way up which are OK. Obviously much cheaper than the Bridge climb but also significantly less memorable too. Recommended for locals or for the very budget conscious first time visitor to Sydney.
Easy climb. We found the climb reasonably easy and the view was spectacular. We sat and watched the film which was a nice relaxing way to end our visit
Easier than walking bridge!. We didn't have the time to do the bridge walk so opted to go up the pylon. Much quicker and easier with excellent views.

worth it. for the budget conscious who want to climb the bridge, this climb up the pylon gets you 2/3 up and gives those great views plus the history of the bridge museum and video are worth your time.

Pylon Lookout. Tiny kids might find this challenging, and when they get to the top they won't be able to see anything, but we found this was a really interesting attraction, walk through the YHA hostel and see the dig site on your way up. Locating the attraction was a bit challenging so some more signage would be a good idea.

A different view. If you don't want to pay the high price for the Bridgeclimb, the Pylon is another option with great views over the bridge. After the Pylon, you can walk across the road deck of the bridge for free then catch the train back to Wynyard, or catch the ferry on the other side outside Luna Park to get some photos from underneath.
was good. Was good before they started charging for entry.Good view from the top of the tower, but not worth paying to walk up 600 steps for it.

Great price for the views you get, bridge climb not required. save yourself some money and do the Pylon lookout instead of the bridge climb. At $13 p/p this was a great opportunity to obtain 360 degree views of the harbour. A previous reviewer advised to catch the train to Milson's Point - this will take you to the far end of the bridge, and you will be required to walk over the bridge as the Pylon lookout is on the south east side. If catching a train, it may be easier to get off at Circular Quay and walk up that way if you are not interested in walking across the bridge itself. The stairwell at the pylon has a seat at each turn, so if you are unfit or unable to handle the stairs in one attempt, feel free to take a seat. The souvenir's were below average, don't expect much in the store. The views are priceless.

Great photo opportunity. We got complimentary tickets for the Pylon following the Bridge Walk. Was nice to get some shots of Sydney from the Pylon as could not take the camera on the Bridge Walk. Interesting video to watch in the museum about the making of the bridge. Nice to see "Dorman Long" mentioned as this is in the Boro (Middlesbrough) where we are from.

A really plesant surprise. My parents had climbed the pylon many moons ago but it's not something myself or family had ever done, so when we got free admission vouchers having just completed BridgeClimb, we went to have a look. I love Sydney Harbour Bridge. With Bridge Climb and the Pylon lookout, we spent almost the whole day going under over around up and down the bridge. Our 8 year old was too young to do BridgeClimb so this was a great way to show her a bit of what we'd seen and a damn sight cheaper too. To be honest the views are just as good as the climb views are and you can take your camera on this trip. The little museum is interesting as is the AV presentation on how the bridge was built. If you can't afford the money or time to do BridgeClimb this is a well worth it alternative.
Photo spot. Given that the bridge has a lot of trafic, is hard to take pictures at night as they come out shaken. However, the Pilon is stable and a perfect spot to get some good shots.
Top of the town. Looking out over the whole of Sydney harbour from an undisturbed unique vantage point. But do your self a favour, take a decent camera for a lifetime of memories
Great views, little pricey. From the top you great a really good view of the opera house and across the harbour and the litle museum on the building of the bridge is interesting, $13 is okay.

Nice views for budget travelers. We debated doing the Sydney BridgeWalk for a while, but ultimately decided it was too expensive for us this time around. We decided that as a compromise, we would pay $13 to go up the Pylon lookout. There was a bit of a museum with some history of the bridge, as well as lovely views at the top. I'm still hoping to do the bridge walk, as I've heard spectacular things, but for travelers that aren't into the adrenaline activities, or simply don't want to spend $250 on the climb, the pylon was a nice substitute for the time being.

Good Value for Money. We were looking at the other options for getting the views from the bridge, but concluded this would be the best view for money. The museum itself is small enough but worth a read to get the history of the bridge before heading out for the views. It lets you appreciate it a little more. The views are spectacular and worth the visit.
Good Lookout to the Sydney Opera House. Good view of the Sydney Opera House and Harbour Bridge. Good spot to know the history of the harbour bridge and photo taking.

Beats the cost of the bridge climb. We climbed the Pylon Lookout and thoroughly enjoyed the view and the accompanying museum. It cost $8 with my Seniors Card as opposed to $248 for the bridge climb. We spent the difference on tea at Doyle's at the Quay. An excellent compromise in our opinion.

Best bang for your buck. At only $13, this view was well worth it! You get all angles around the south east pylon, including other parts of the city that I haven't seen photographed as heavily. I got a great look at the Harbour and Opera House, of course, also. Great photo opportunity!

Fantastic views. Walked across bridge on road. Pylons had great displays and lots of historical photos and information. Also a lovely gift shop
The views from the top were fantastic, well worth the effort of climbing the steps!

If the bridge climb is a little too much..... Just a couple of hundred steps gets you high enough up to get some great pics of the Opera house and some close ups of the bridge and surrounding areas - worth a wander up here.

BEST VIEWS OF SYDNEY. NOT TO BE MISSED!. Thought you might want to do the Sydney Harbour Bridge walk ... save yourself the $200-$300 and do this instead! 360 degree views, look DOWN onto the bridge walkers, visit the museum and learn about the history of the bridge in film ... ALL for the grand sum of only $13. This has to be the best kept secret of Sydney tourism without question.

Great views. We went to the Pylon Lookout (AUD13 per person) instead of the Bridge Climb which would have cost us AUD$248. The views from this Pylon is just as great as from the top of the bridge (in our opinion), very breathtaking and it does provide a 360 degree view.The 200 steps is a much more easy tackle than the bridge climb. It suits people at every fitness level. Unfortunately, the ticket counter cashier for that day was not interested in the guests that were there. We greeted him to deaf ears, he was more interested in "surfing the internet"

Who needs to climb the Bridge?. Looked into climbing the Bridge for our family of four would have taken 4 hours and cost over $800 so instead for under $50 we went up the pylon.Yep given not as high as the top of the Bridge but really not worth the extra money once you have seen the views from the top of the pylon. Spectacular 360 degree views of the harbour and some of the best are looking down the road along the Bridge.Movie introduction to give you a breif histroy of the Bridge and plenty of information for even the most avid history buffs.Good old souvenir shop selling the same old stuff.Give yourselves an hour to fully appreciate the pylon then continue to walk across the Bridge at great way to spend the afternoon.

Value for money. Don't bother with the bridge climb at 245 AUD plus 80 AUD for photo pack. Climb up 200 steps for 13 AUD to top of the Pylon Lookout and get 360 degree view of Sydney Harbour nearly at same level as top of bridge and take your own photos. Value for money and you don't need to be breathalysed, spend half a day on safety briefing and wear a dodgy boiler suit

great value for $$$ also great for children. cost us $50 for 2 adults and 4 children (one was free as under 5) it was a great experience for the kids, lots of interesting facts about the bridge and the view at the top is almost as good as the view at the top of the bridge. :)

Excellent View of the Harbour. The adventurous "must do" bridgeclimb at AUD249 per person for a family of 5 is incredibly expensive, and it would cost over AUD1,000. We therefore opt for this cheaper alternative at AUD48 for the entire family, including a five-year-old. The climb was a little sweaty and was well worth it. Great 360 views, good education on some history, and overall very enjoyable. I highly recommend this.

Worth the climb. Great views and once you have completed the climb and descend,there are various items of interest concerning the building of the bridge including a cinematographic slide show.This is free if you do the bridge climb, for use on another day
Experience well worth it. Very safe climb, do not be put off by heights as it is an easy climb, and safety has been captured along the way. Lots of people climb it every day so just do it!

These are the memories of the bridge. Did the harbour bridge climb and got free access to the pylon. But it is definitely worth the price of entry. Here's where you are able to take photos and get the memories of our trip to Sydney

Incredible. This is an excellent alternative to the much-hyped (and expensive) Sydney Bridge Climb. For just £5 you get a fantastic view of the bridge itself and sweeping views of the harbour and Opera House.
Great Views. This is a great alternative to the more expensive and time consuming bridge walk. Not quite as high, but still a fantastic view of the harbour and surrounds.

Breathtaking at a lower height. Many of us are not too thrilled by the idea of climbing the Harbour Bridge, mainly due to their fear of heights. So why should you miss out capturing the beauty of one of the magnificent harbours in the world? From the Rocks, there are steps to the Harbour Bridge where it is just a short stroll to the southern pylon. Be prepared to walk up 200 steps - but not all at once. There are many landings along the way and this little museum has some remarkable photos taken as the bridge was being built. You will actually see what holds this structure together! Well worth the walk!

Fascinating insight to the Bridge. The story of the bridge from conception to the grand opening; artefacts, tales from those involved and great views of the Bridge. A worthwhile visit if you prefer not to .walk the bridge'.

Climbing an alternative to the bridge climb. I went on this climb as a teenager and didn't even notice that there were so many steps. The scenery from the top is just as spectacular as the bridge climb. Now I am older the climb isn't so easy, so do it whilst you are young

Great views. For those who don't have the time or $ to do the Bridge Climb, the Pylon Lookout is the next best thing. Great views, at a fraction of the price of Bridge Climb. 150 steps, each way and seniors get in for $8.50 - a real deal in Sydney!

One of the biggest surprises of our holiday. We went to the Pylon lookout expecting to be able to climb to the top and get a great view of the city (which we did), but did not expect the "museum" inside the pylon, which was a very intersting history of the background to the build the polical climate, the personalities etc. First class

Fanastic view and very interesting history. There is a great bit of history on the making of the bridge and the view from the top is just as good as from the top of the arc. I was surprised to find how interesting the making of a bridge could be too!

Interesting Museum, Great Views. We did not have time to go and do the walk over the top,of the bridge so went to the Pylon Lookout instead. While at the top admiring the wonderful views over the harbour, dark clouds appeared over the city and a great display of lightening started. We were ushered from the top lookout and viewed the storm from bridge deck level and it was all great fun until the very large bang and flash as lightening hit the bridge structure above. No damage to the people who all jumped very high and landed safely. Unforgettable and worthwhile on a sunny day too!

Great views and some history. Did the bridge climb a week prior with my daughter, as my wife is afraid of heights. Used the included admission to the pylon so my wife could get a sense of the scale of the bridge. The pylon has a number of static displays that I found interesting and learned much more than I had on the bridge climb. For anyone who is afraid of heights and confined spaces, the Pylon is a an excellent alternative to bridge climb.

Save some money but still get some great views. We decided it was to expensive (and hot) to do the 'bridge walk' and so went up the pylon tower just above the rocks. You get great views probably as good as from the bridge walk and you can take plenty of photos which you cannot do on the bridge walk.It is not the easiest place to find from the rocks so get a map from the tourist information shop and ask them for directions.

Great Views. It isn't as adventurous as the Bridge Climb, but the views are spectacular. There are a lot of stairs to climb to the lookout, but I didn't find it very strenuous. Along the way there are displays about the building of the bridge. I was there on a weekday afternoon and it was not crowded.

Bird's eye view of Sydney. If Sydney Harbour Bridge climb is too adventurous or pricey for you, Pylon Lookout Point is another place where you can enjoy the bird's eye view of Sydney. A strongly recommended place to visit!

Views, views!. If you want a magnificent view of Sydney Harbour, in all it's glory, the pylon lookout is a must. It's not always easy to find the path to it but well with the effort. There's a small museum with fascinating displays on the building of the bridge - an architectural and engineering masterpiece. The reward on climbing the stairs to the lookout- Sydney Harbour - surely one of the most beautiful sights in the world.
Outstanding. Beat bargain going, incredible view, our kids didn't want to leave. The bridge climb might be great too, but not at 20x the cost!
Great view. Providing a great alternative to the bridge climb. Plenty of things to learn about the building of the bridge and early sydney.
Good if you have time to pass. The 'museum' and information boards are interesting, but it's not a must see or do. The view is pretty.

Excellent vfm well worth a visit. Visited the bridge early one morning - quite tricky to find easy pedestrian access so check you maps/guide books carefully. Excellent historical background to the building as you go up the tower with superb views from the top - note quite the bridge walk but at several 100 dollars cheaper this is by far the best option. Helpful staff and a good gift shop with reasonable prices. Much better than expected highly recommended

Great views and great value. A relatively inexpensive way of getting great views of Sydney Harbour and the surrounding area. Stairs on Argyll Street take you to the main deck and then its just a short walk to the Pylon Lookout. There is a small shop and ticket sales and then it's 200 easy stairs to the top and the marvellous views. Last time we were there the cats were still in residence but sadly they are no longer there. Plenty of history about the construction of the bridge and the challenges they faced. Well worth a visit especially on a clear day.
Why no lift?. A fantastic view from the top of the Pylon, but at our advanced age we had to stop lots of times for a 'blow' on the way up. A lift would have been more than welcome!

Great inexpensive option to BridgeClimb. Climb up the inside of the south pylon of Sydney Harbour Bridge for 1/20th cost of BridgeClimb. Excellent Opera House, Harbour, City views. You can also walk across the pedestrian walkway from The Rocks to Kirribilli on the north side of the harbour, descend to visit Luna Park on the waterfront and catch the ferry back to Circular Quay. There is also a pedestrial walkway above the railline at Circular Quay from the Botanic Gardens along the Cahill Expressway to The Rocks. Glass lift east of Circular Quay railway station. Other alternative can include a round walk from Circular Quay to Opera House, around Farm Cove, thru the Botanic Gardens, along the Cahill Expressway walkway past the Rocks and onto the Pylon.

Spectacular views. The pylon gives you a great aerial view of the Sydney Harbor. They say that it's only 200 steps to the top but that's only if you don't count the stairs you have to climb to get to the bridge deck. Once you are on the bridge deck you have to walk a few hundred meters to the pylon entrance. It's not an easy climb if you're out of shape (like I am) but there are several stops along the way so that you learn the history of the bridge. The stops give you a good reason to catch your breath on the way up. And, of course, there is a gift shop near the top that gives you another reason to take a break on the way up. At $13 for the ticket, I think it is well worth the cost to see the view from the top of the pylon.

Great place for a photo op. I was expecting very little from this place, but was surprised. You enter through a very inconspicuous doorway in the pylon and up a few flights of stairs. Then after you pay your entry fee, you climb some more stairs to small museum and gift shop. The museum explains how the bridge was built, why it was built and the politics surrounding it. You then climb some more stairs to a room near the top of the Pylon where you can get some great photos of the city and the harbor. As you leave there is a short movie about the bridge, which has no commentary, but shows some photos of it being built. I went here to learn about the bridge - I had wanted to do a bridge walk, but the money they were asking was outrageous, so I was happy with this as a more reasonable way to learn more about this iconic structure.
Even better than the Brigde climb. Ideal for backpackers who don't have the money to go on the bridge climb. The lookout give you for a few bucks a million dollar view.

Great views. The pylon is the low cost way to get a great aerial view of the Sydney Harbor if you do not want to pay the price to make the bridge climb. We did both and we were happy for both experiences.

Well worth the climb. It took a lot of will power and perseverance for me to climb the 200 stairs to the top (its all mind over matter so I'm told! but I get very queasy when I can see through stairs and end up in a lather of sweat) However, once at the top the views were spectacular. Enjoyed reading the history of the bridge which is on display.

Cheaper alternative to bridge climb. Views up on top are spectacular, all Sydneysiders are very proud of the Sydney Harbour. It also tells you the history of how the bridge was built, how many nuts and bolts were used and all the other statistics. If you don't want to fork out the cost to climb the bridge itself, this would be an excellent second choice.

A view from above that spares you the climb. There is an option to climb the pylon of the bridge for a small fee. this options allows one a bird's eye view without a big climb. there is also a museum to see in the pylon. A great experience anyone can enjoy.

Great views and cheap!. If you can't afford to do the bridge climb (or you're afraid of heights!), I'd recommend the pylon lookout. It used to be free, but now you have to pay, however it's a fraction of the cost of the bridge climb and you still get a great view of the surroundings.

Great view. I climbed the harbour bridge on my 1st trip to Sydney 12 years ago . I found this climb to be obviously easier, but it also had the massive advantage of giving you the flexibility to stay up there for as long as you want , & more importantly for me, to be able to take my camera & take as many photos as I wanted . I was also lucky enough to be at the top as a massive cruise liner left the harbour

Who would believe I was scared of heights!. This walk up the pylons was a great treat as my family did the harbour bridge climb but I was too scared.To reach the top of the pylons and look out without fear because of the high concrete barrier was such a thrill, and the view.... Breathtaking!

Great first activity in Sydney. Family of 4 (2 adults 2 teenagers) did this as a cheaper alternative to the Bridgeclimb. Great activity to do at the start of your holiday as a taster of what Sydney has to offer. The views from the top are wonderful. The walk to the top can be broken up into stages as the bridge history is covered as you climb higher. Please note that if you do the Bridgeclimb you get free passes to do the Pylon lookout.

You gotta be fit. It's a hard climb to the top of the pylon but it's a really nice view and there's plenty of interpretive boards inside to read on your way up the stairs which are a great excuse to stop and get your breath back!

decent view but nothing amazing. we like doing bridge walks so we walked from milsons point to pylon lookout and then to the rocks but the view from Pylon isn't amazing, there's a glass piece that goes around the top that kind of makes it awkward to take pics (if you want to be in the pic), scenery pics aren't difficult of course since there's a step up for you to reach over the glass

Excellent value for money. This is excellent value for money and a very good alternative, if you are wary about doing the bridge climb or think it too expensive. The views from the top of the pylon of Sydney Harbour are impressive and extensive. You also have very good, close up views of those who are climbing the bridge. There are a lot of steps to climb inside the pylon, but these are in stages, as on the way up there are exhibitions about the building of the bridge. There is plenty of space in which to rest ,if necessary. After climbing the pylon, we walked the whole length of the bridge and caught a ferry from Luna Park back to Circular Quay. We felt that we saw some impressive sights that morning and were pleased with our decision to take this alternative to the bridge climb.

Amazing View. My partner went for the bridge climb and got a complimentary ticket for Pylon Lookout, which was great for an acrophobic like me.It was one of the windiest day, I was almost blown off at the entrance, so was a guy who was three times my size. The lookout was great. There were interesting stories about Sydney and the bridge. I had an amazing view of Sydney from there.The mini video at the end of the visit was nice and moving.

Poorly signposted attraction. We spent a lot of time looking for this. We had been to the markets in The Rocks and walked up the hill at the end of the markets. A look to the left and we saw the signpost to the bridge climb only so we walked to the left towards the pylon. When we got there, we realised we could not get in and the entrance was from near the bridge. We rang someone and was told to follow the signs to the bridge climb. Eventually found one signpost. Walked past the bridge office and there was a small sign pointing to the stairwell. We went up the stairs to the top only to find that we should have turned off at the middle exit - no signpost to tell you this. Eventually got there but very annoyed. Hope there were better signposts for people coming from different directions. Pylon lookout was good in the end but our view was clouded by the frustration.

Stunning views!. I did the Bridge Climb back in 2008 and returned to Sydney last year. I didn't want to spent that much money again but still wanted to see the great views I've seen back then. I've read about the Lookout on Tripadvisor and thought I could try it. And I found it incredible!This is definitely a nice substitute if you do not want to pay that much money on the bridge climb or just want to see the most stunning views over the harbour again.And what I liked best was that you can take pictures which you can't if you do the bridge climb! You can find the lookout at the pylon that is closest to the harbour, the South East Pylon. Use the 'Bridge Stairs' in Cumberland Street, The Rocks to get to the pedestrian pathway to find the entrance!
Brilliant view. really good view of Sydney, good value for money and lots of history about the bridge, if booking the bridge climb you get a free ticket to visit the pylon

Just Wow. This was recommended to us by a local as a good, cheap alternative to the bridge climb. And I'm glad we listened. Price for entry was reasonable and the walk to the top (200 steps if I recall) was not difficult and anyone with a reasonable level of fitness could cope quite easily. There are two exhibition levels on the way up with some good information about the history of the bridge and allows those struggling with the climb a breather. The view from the top was breathtaking. It wasn't busy at all even though it was school holidays so moving around the limited space at the top and taking photos was not a problem. It's probably best to get a map and some directions from the visitor centre at The Rocks on finding your way to the walkway leading to the pylon as it's not as straightforward as you might think.

Super experience & excellent value. Apart from just standing back and admiring Sydney Harbour Bridge, you can also walk across it on the pavement (for free), walk over the arch itself (around $300) or walk to the top of one of the pylons. Access to all is via steps on Cumberland Street - just follow the brown signs.We did the first and third of these paying just $7 with seniors concession (don't forget your passport for proof of age) for the Pylon walk.There are around 80 steps to climb but it doesn't take long and there are seats and water fountains at several points so don't be put off. There is also a lot of very interesting information about the bridge and its history.Needless to say, the views from the top of the pylon are fabulous. I was originally going to do the arch climb but was really glad I chose not to. Apart from it being ridiculously expensive, you have to go at your booked slot and you can be very unlucky with the weather. The pylon option just involves turning up when you fancy it.We thoroughly enjoyed it and highly recommend it.

One of Sydney's iconic landmarks. Wherever you are in Sydney harbour, you have great views of this majestic structure that we all recognise instantly when we see it.Apparently there was debate for many years about whether or not it should be built but thankfully it was. I doubt the business case fully appreciated that the bridge and Opera House would pull in so much tourism.Apart from just standing back and admiring you can also walk across it on the pavement (for free), walk over the arch itself (around $300) or walk to the top of one of the pylons. Access to all is via steps on Cumberland Street - just follow the brown signs.We did the first and third of these paying just $7 with seniors concession (don't forget your passport for proof of age) for the Pylon walk.There are around 80 steps to climb but it doesn't take long and there are seats and water fountains at several points so don't be put off. There is also a lot of very interesting information about the bridge and its history.Needless to say, the views from the top of the pylon are fabulous. I was originally going to do the arch climb but was really glad I chose not to. Apart from it being ridiculously expensive, you have to go at your booked slot and you can be very unlucky with the weather. The pylon option just involves turning up when you fancy it.You can also of course sail under it and this too comes highly recommended. There are many options from public ferries to private charters so take your pick.Whatever your preference, the bridge is magnificent.

Economical alternative to Bridge Climb. We wanted to get the view from the Bridge, but didn't want to spend 3 hours and $almost $500 to climb the bridge. Instead, we choose the Pylon Lookout. This is probably the best value attraction in all of Sydney. The views from the Pylon were wonderful.
Fantastic Views. We climbed the pylon and it is well worth the trek as the view is amazing. There is quite a few stairs so just be mindful if you have any walking issues.

A good alternative view of the Bridge .... If you don't fancy doing the walk up the bridge the Pylon allows to to go inside and see the displays of how the bridge was built at then you can go out to get great views of the bridge from up high. Well worth a visit.
Well Worth the Effort!. The views were breathtaking, and the movie on the making of the bridge brought me to tears with how the builders poured their sweat over it without a bit of safety equipment!

Excellent option for seeing the harbor. I chose to not take the bridge climb ($235) but opted for the pylon climb ($13) instead. I had only three days in Sydney, so spending half a day (and maybe all of my daily energy) on the climb did not seem like a reasonable proposal to me.The climb is relatively easy, and the views are fantastic. The climb is well worth the cost. I rank it as my number one activity in my short stay in Sydney (very enjoyable). Make sure you map out your walk before you start your hike….I had to back-track to get to the road/walkway leading to the pylon (there is no place to climb at the base of the pylon).

Great & Cost-effective Alternative to the Harbour Bridge Climb. My husband and I originally intended to do the bridge climb. The more we discussed it, however the more convinced we became that the experience wasn't worth the price for us. We found the view from the Pylon Lookout to be great. Admission is inexpensive, and we learned a lot. Follow signs for the Harbour Bridge to the Pylon entrance. There are exhibits throughout the climb.

Great Views and Very Economical. We climbed the pylon (AUS$27.00 for two) rather than pay AUS$280-$320 each for the Bridge Climb. We had great views, then walked on the bridge's pedestrian walkway out to the center of the span for more nice views and cool breezes.

Don't miss the SHB Pylon. I wanted to take my Dad and Brother up the Bridge but due to Christmas, our pockets wouldn't allow it. Instead, we ventured up the southern pylon and were blown away by the view - almost equally the experience at the top of the bridge! Totally recommended as a cheap alternative to Bridge Climb (which I've also done and love!!)

Great experience for a great price. We decided to enjoy the views from the Pylon Lookout as an alternative to climbing the bridge, and we weren't disappointed! The walk up the stairs to the overlook location is not as high as we expected so my mother (who is in need of a hip replacement) was able to make it without any problem as long as she took a couple of short breaks on the way up the stairs. The walk to the lookout point also includes interesting information about the bridge and a water fountain, which was appreciated.I recommend that you plan to go early in the morning when it opens at 10am because it is a small overlook point and can be hard to get your desired photos as more people arrive.

great if free with climb. expensive and I probably wouldnt bother if you are paying to go in, if you got a free ticket as part of your bridge climb then definately dont waste it. my problem is not that its not a worthy attraction, but the standalone entrance charge is a bit steep for what it is.

Best views of Sydney. The views at the top of the pylons are worth the low admission price. Today I went I was shocked to see how few people were at the pylon Lookout. You get a 360° panoramic view of the entire city. The only view that I found better than this was the much more expensive bridge climb. You're not allowed to take up a camera for the bridge climb.Anyone who could climb about 200 stairs should go to the pylon Lookout while they visit Sydney.

200 steps to a great view. This is a great cheap alternative to the bridge walk if you suffer with a fear of heights. You also get free admission if you do the bridge walk so I gave my pass to my husband who wasn't climbing. The pictures, video and information about the bridge are the same as on the bridge climb. Once there, great panoramic views of the iconic harbour. Great way to spend an hour.

If you are not game or do not have time for the Bridge Climb this is the thing to do. This is a dead easy and cheap way to get great views of the city, the harbour and the Parramatta River. Not too many stairs, you can take as much time as you like and you can easily include it into your stroll across the bridge.

Brilliant views in every direction. It is most definitely worth climbing up the stairs to see the views from up here! You can see the Opera house, Circular Quay, the CBD and walk right around the Pylon. There isnt a lot of room to move but it wasn;t too busy when we went mid-afternoon. There was a bit of a wind so i would recommend taking a jersey on a cooler day. There are a few information displays around the pylon and on a couple of different levels as a bit of a bonus. Definitely one of the first things to do when you get to Sydney :)

What a view. The walk to the Pylon Lookout is good and once you reach the lookout the view is spectacular. I never get tired of looking at Sydney Harbour. A great little excursion any time of the year.

Stunning views. Great views of the Sydney CBD and Circular Quay at a really reasonable price. Pretty cool being out in the open air as well. I am guessing it would get pretty cramped up there when it's busy and there is not a lot of room too move around, we went mid afternoon and it was reasonably quiet. Definitely recommend when visiting Sydney even if only a short visit.

Good views, but lots of stairs to walk up. The views from the Lookout are good, but I think it is overpriced. I suggest you walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge via the pedestrian walkway instead. It is free and take about 20 minutes each way.

Great place to visit. Scared of heights so was anxious to go but wow was I mistaken. A great view on everything you'd like to see on the skyline including the opera house. And all of that for a cheap price. Worth the visit.
Worthwhile. Did not feel up to the bridge climb so walked across the pedestrian route then went up the pylon. Great views, lots of info about the bridge (but not too much !) well worth the cost.

good view on a budget. we got free tickets from a bridge climb the previous day and the view is good together with a lot of the history of the build.
on a good day you get a great view

Sydney Pylon lookout. Walking across the bridge is an experience well worth doing but climbing up to the Pylon lookout is even better there are a few stairs but not too difficult to manage It is a lot cheaper than climbing the bridge Views from the pylon are amazing looking across the Harbour and Sydney you can see the tall ships and ferries there is so much to see and some marvelous photo opportunities

Excellent value - Sydney's big secret. Short on time and money - skip the bridge climb and go up the pylon. Views are amazing. Interesting information/displays. No delays / uniforms / OHS talks / outrageous fees.

Good views of Sydney.. Could not afford the bridge climbing so the next best option was to climb the ppylon. Lots of stairs but is worth taking the effort. Also you can do the walkway which goes right acxross the bridge, for free, then take a ferry back.

Super - recommendable. If you don't want to do the expensive bridge climb this is a great option. Its cheaper, easy to reach with a minimal effort and gives you a great view of Sydney Harbour. Definately recommendable.
Very good. Easy, cheap and well worth the fairly minimal effort. I would recommend this to anyone visiting Sydney, especially on a nice day.

Good view with cheap price. Pylon lookout does offer a great view of sydney harbour, the city and the bridge. However, I can't agree with most reviews overly praising the views as being the best/perfect. However, the ticket is really cheap and for the price, I would still recommend going up for the view

Well priced, great views and enough info. We got the student rate which was really well priced.
All the information provided is brilliant as well as the short historical montage.
The views are the best thing though and we were the only ones up there when we went.

Perfect Views!. Travelled up to the top today on my birthday, the views were absolutely stunning, it was unbelievable how beautiful it was. You can see Sydney from all directions at the top and the museum inside is very informative. There are 200 steps to climb from the eastern pedestrian walkway from the Harbour Bridge but it hardly takes long, and there are many seats to rest on towards the way up. The views were definitely worth the climb.

Great views without climbing the bridge. This is a much cheaper and quicker way of getting a really good view of the Harbour, Opera house and circular quay than by climbing the bridge or going up the Sydney tower.The 200 steps don't take very long to climb, and the view is really good.... it really is worth it.I went up the Sydney Tower last time I came to Sydney, and this view of the Harbour is certainly just as good.

The title says it all. Fabulous views from up top. There is museum as well plus a film to watch re construction of the Bridge. Can watch the Bridge Climbers too. Was not allowed to do the Bridge Climb due to medical history (even tho I'd climbed Snowdon a month before). However the Pylon is much cheaper but does have 200 steps!. The entrance is from the pedestrian walkway across the Bridge, not from the Pylon base.

THE PYLON MUSEUM AND LOOK OUT IS A CHEAPER ALTERNATIVE. We were a family of four and decided that the Sydney Harbour Bridge climb was probably too much physically for our youngest son and was an exepensive outing. We then found the alternative of the pylon museum. The little museum was very informative and also gave some magnificant views of Sydney Harbour and the Bridge. Afterwards, we walked along to the walkway along the bridge which was amazing and surprisingly short. A great morning of fantastic sights and Sydney history.

Just as good as the Bridge Climb.. We chose to do the Pylon Lookout as it is a lot cheaper and takes half the time than if we did the Bridge Climb. We were lucky with very few others doing the 200 stairs and we were rewarded with a fabulous view of the harbour and the bridge. Two children (12&10) did it very easy, but make sure you wear lots of sunscreen and take advantage of the water along the stair climb. Very worth it!
Great view for a bargain price. $13 for a million dollar view! Great photo opportunity and beautiful 360* views of the whole city. The stairs weren't too strenuous - don't let them put you off!

The view without the huge price!. This is an excellent way to get almost the same view as from the Harbour Bridge Climb but without the time involved or the cost.We have taken many overseas visitors here with great reviews from the experience. It's also not as well known to overseas visitors as the Bridge Climb & doesn't require prior booking.
Great climb. This is a great climb for people who do not like the idea of the full climb or for children who are too young to climb the bridge. Reasonably priced and an awesome view.
Great views. I don't know why one would spend 15x more for the bridge climb, as this lookout is already terrific and probably only a few dozen meters lower. Also some informative exhibitions.

Great value for money. I was tipped off about this by the owner of the b & b where I was staying who said you must do this instead of the bridge climb, and I'm glad I did.You still get all the history of the bridge, get great views from the top and the bonus is that you can take your own photos.Gift shop, exhibits and a video of the history of the building of the bridge made this a very enjoyable experience.

Sydney Harbour Bridge Pylon lookout and history display. The 360 degree view of Sydney from the Southern Pylon is fabulous. It is only $13 pp and very worthwhile. Leave time to have a look at the small museum which has interesting facts and figures about the construction.

Big views without the big price. My visit to the Pylon Lookout was included free with the cost of the bridge climb (which I did earlier the same day), normal price for entry is $13, . There's about 6 flights of stairs to the ticket desk, then another six to a little gift shop, followed by about six more flights to the top, every second landing has a bench for resting. I was beginning to get breathless when I got to the top as I'm late sixties and did them all non-stop.:-) . I found the entry price to be reasonable as you get great views of the city, harbour, opera house and bridge. You can access the bridge walkway, which leads to the pylon lookout, from the steps on Cumberland St.

Great views for a great price. Everyone talks about the Bridge Climb but the price was just not value for money. And apparently you can't carry your camera up there anyway. So here's a way to get great views of the Sydney Harbour and the Opera House for a great price.You can walk all around the Pylon and get great views. Check out the historical info along the way up to the lookout.Look carefully at the glass all around the lookout...there's lots of info there too.
Steeped in History and a feat of man for that era. The Bridge climb (very safe) is wonderful and the view is incredible. Perfect view of the Sydney Opera House.
Go to the Pylon Lookout - best view of the harbour!. great view of the harbour, for very little money (was around 10 AUD) to get to the observation deck, with views in all directions.

Great views and you can bring a camera. This is an easy and less expensive way to get a great view of the harbor and the Opera House. We were thinking of doing the walk to the top of the bridge until we found out you can't take a camera. It's some stairs but it is not hard. There is also an informative movie.

Great views of Sydney from the Bridge Pylon. A less expensive way to get great views of Sydney and the Harbour. Lots of steps but you can rest part of the way up by taking time to learn the history of the bridge in the showroom/gift shop. Take your camera or binoculars up with you. Walk around the Pylon for virtually a 360 degree view. Probably a better solution to the Bridge Climb for those who like feel more secure underfoot. You can complete your Bridge walk heading North from the Pylon across to Milsons Point and the railway station at the other end of the bridge and then take the train back to Wynyard Station if you choose not to walk back.

Cheaper than the bridge climb/same view. At the advise of one of my buddies I did this instead of the bridge climb and long story short it was well worth it. The views from the Pylon are great from each side and the posted material along the way is super informative. Give yourself 2 hours to make the climb and take photos. For $13 per person, it was one of the best values we've encountered.

Great alternative trip to the "bridge walk". We didn't want to spend the extortionate amount they charge for the bridge walk, so took our $13 to the Pylon and had a great visit. You can take a camera (you can't on the bridge walk!) so you get to take loads of pictures of the bridge and Opera House. Not too many steps and gift shop near the top.

Alternative to climbing the bridge. Climbing the bridge seemed a little too energetic and it is also quite expensive, so we embarked on the Pylon Lookout. It is still energetic - lots of steps, but the view is worth the climb and it is good value - especially if you buy an activity card which gives you access to lots of attractions.
harbourbridge pylon. had an amazing walk up pylon with incredible views of harbour just before boarding our cruise to the south pacific great experience sure to do again.

Inexpensive Option to Bridge Climb. Museum alone is worth the $11, and the views are probably almost as good as from the top of the bridge. If you have the ability to do the bridge climb and have $200 (per person) to pay for the opportunity, it's probably an opportunity not to be missed, but we had a lot of fun with the $189 saved by climbing the pylon. Caveat: there aren't any options for the mobility impaired.

Beautiful view of the entire city. Good to visit at the start of the trip.. I really enjoyed the Pylon Lookout because it gave me a panoramic view of the entire city. We visited this place at the beginning of the trip which was nice because it gave me a feel of how big the city is and which direction certain landmarks were located. I highly recommend it. Great for pictures of the view or of yourself in a scenic background :)
Wonderful panoramic view. Walked across the bridge and on the way back we went up the Pylon Lookout to enjoy the wonderful views

Great value for money, and a great alternative to the climb. If you've seen my review for the bridge climb itself, you'll know that whilst I enjoyed it, for me it is extremely over priced. The Pylon Lookout is a better alternative in my view, on account of the fact that it is cheap to get in to ($15 per person). It is effectively a museum inside and provides a lot of interesting information about the bridge itself. The lookout itself is also at a similar height to the top of the bridge, and you can take your own pictures (something which you cannot do on the bridge climb). All in all I can only highly recommend this, whether you've done the bridge climb or not. TOP TIP: Entry to the Pylon Lookout is free when you do the bridge climb, so it's worth doing even if you have done the climb on account of the fact that you can take your own pictures with the same view.

Cheaper than the bridge climb. Although not as fancy as the bridge climb, this is worth it especially if you are interested in the history of the bridge and want to take photos from the top with your own camera. Thee are stairs, but you can go at your own pace. You also have to pay - when I did the bridge climb I got a token to go up here for free. The views are nice and you don't have to book so can pick a nice day or go up for sunset etc. nice to do if you're walking over the bridge and have time to stop.
Pylon Museum. Excellent. The 300 steps to the top of the pylon aren't really that bad, especially when you see the view from the top.
Easy climb.. The steps up are not too hard if you take your time. The views from the top are fantastic and this is a much cheaper way to see the bridge than on climbing over the bridge.
A long walk for an okay view. If you like exercise and stairs then take this climb.. however, there are better areas for better views.

Great views. We got free entry after doing the bridge climb. The view from the top is great and unlike the bridge where you can't take photos on top of here you can which means it's slightly better as you take your own. There are a couple of levels which tell the story of the history of the bridge and old photos

Great views and well priced. A great 360 degree view of the harbour and Sydney. You have to climb the stairs inside the pylon to reach the top but there are a number of exhibits and places to stop on the way up. Took an 8 year old up and he loved it.

A great way to learn about the bridge and see Sydney ..... The Pylon Lookout is situated on top of part of the structure of Sydney Harbour Bridge. For those we either can not afford the Sydney Harbour Bridge Walk itself, or maybe do not feel up to it , the Pylon is a great way to get a similar view to the Bridge Walk at a fraction of the cost, around $12 ASD.A great bonus in doing the walk, as in my case, is that you get free tickets for two people to the Pylon Lookout. If you do both then make sure you do the Pylon first as it is a bit of an anti climax, as to be expected, if you do the bridge walk first.There is no lift to the top of the lookout but the steps, around two hundred as east to climb, wide and internal. There are exhibitions and notices to read on the way up to educate you about the Pylon which is granite faced and does not actually hold the bridge up itself.There is a small gift shop at the bottom of the Pylon where you can buy entry tickets and all sorts of souvenirs, The lookout itself is a walkway around the top of the pylon which has a ridge that you can use as a step, good for children, or sit on out of the wind. It provides a full view of Sydney and the surrounds which is great. You can take your camera, unlike the Bridge Walk, so make sure you do as the views are amazing.All in all well worth a visit and for the family a great experience and different way to see stunning Sydney.
Great views. Wonderful views of harbour and surrounds. Only 200 steps to climb, good value for money and well signposted.

Amazing views. Great views over the harbour and the Circular Quay. At $11 it's probably much better than the $200+ Bridge Walk, especially since you can't take a camera.and make photos on the latter. Highly recommended!

one step two step keep on going. despite the many steps involved, this was a wonderful way to view Sydney. We considered doing the bridge walk but decided the time commitment wasn't worth it. This lookout provide ample views and a very reasonable cost, especially for the kids. They keep it relatively simple. but it's worth the walk.

We found a surprise. Knowing Sydney very well, I thought I had covered all the major sights and attractions. But the Pylon Lookout was a new and most rewarding experience. There is plenty on the amazing history of the construction of the bridge as well as spectacular views from the top. There are plenty if stairs to climb but it is well worth it
Great view. Sydney is an awesome city and this is one of the many great places to see the spectacular sky line. With the wildfire smoke hanging over the city it was an awesome picture spot

No Safety Harness Necessary!. We could have spent $200 apiece to climb the Bridge. But somehow the thought of looking hundreds of metres down to the Harbour with the wind in our hair and nothing between us and the water but a safety cable seemed a bit too much for it. Instead we spent $11 each to ascend to the pylon lookout. Amazing views, a little history, and a settled stomach. Not to mention an extra $380 in our pockets!

Great view. What more to say?! A great view if you have time to spend in the city, but if you're on a short stay don't make the effort - concentrate on Circular Quay and the walk through the Botanical Garden and over to Mrs. Macquarie's Chair.

Amazing views. Walking across the bridge was the first thing we did after arriving in Sydney. The pylon lookout was just opening when we walked by so we decided to check it out. It's a great little museum about the building of the bridge. Lots of pictures and information. The views from the lookout are awesome.
great views. must do for any tourist, although a bit pricy to enter, but well worth the view of the bridge and harbour
There is a charge. The signage on the bridge deck does not indicate there is a fee it just indicates you can get a view from higher.

The Climb. Worth the walk, from the rocks to the pylon (along the bridge) and to the top of pylon by steps, great view over the the rocks and overlooking sydney harbour to the distance. Excellant view of Sydney Harbour from top of the pylon.
Worth the Climb up the Pylon. Well worth the entrance fee of $11 each to visit the museum and climb the pylon, beautiful views and you can spend as much time as you want there
Kids LOVED this!. Our children really enjoyed this. We got some incredible shots of the harbour. They also enjoyed watching the people climbing the Harbour bridge.

bring your camera (hopefully a good one...). first of all, the entry is not free.the entry was $10, but it was really worth the money.the view is stunning. fortunately i brought a 70-200 and a 16-35 with me. we were also very lucky. we went there in a weekend afternoon. there were not many tourists. beautiful blue sky with scattered clouds. ALL the photos i took that afternoon are stunning. if you come to visit sydney, i certainly recommend this place to you and strongly suggest you to bring a good(dslr or mirrorless) camera with you. btw, if you want to pick one place between pylon point and the tv tower, and you are a photographer, just skip the tv tower.

Pylon Lookout at Sydney Harbour Bridge. Often overlooked for the BridgeClimb, the lookout at the bridge pylon offers amazing panoramic view of the harbour and city skyline, at a fraction of the cost of bridge climb. It is also at the top of an interesting museum which celebrates the construction of the massive bridge. I actually prefer it over the BridgeClimb.

Great lookout!. Reached about half the highest point that the Bridge climb folks would reach but the views are still the same! Good value for just $11 with magnificent views! And I can snap as many photos as I wish!

Splendid views of the city, the harbour and the river. If you are not game for the Bridge Climb then climb the pylon. It is an easy climb up the internal stairs, just take your time if you are not at your fittest. Once at the top there are magnificent views all around. Just pause there, go around a least a couple of times and savour the views of the cityscape, the harbour the bridge - girders and deck, and up river.

A better view than the Eye Tower.. Not only is the view better than the Eye Tower, it is also much cheaper. The view of the Opera House and it's surroundings are phenomenal. The trip up the stairs is broken up with history of the bridge. Well worth a trip.

The Bridge Climb for those on a budget. Perhaps this title does not give the Pylon Lookout the proper justice.
The views are spectacular, but so is the history of the bridge depicted in the exhibits below.
Quite simply an excellent way to enjoy the amazing vistas of harbour-side Sydney.

Good views. Only access is by walking and climbing stairs so an average level of fitness is required. Well worth it for the views at the top. Good information & insight into the building and how the bridge came to be built.

A great experience!. We were given vouchers for free entry when we checked in for our Harbour Bridge climb. There is a lot of information on the way up and around the ledges at the top of the Pylon. The views are spectacular and you ard able to take a camera up and take your own photos.

Outstanding Way to Experience Sydney. Absolutely beautiful and great learning experience. Good view of the Rocks, Opera House, and harbor. Located in one of the bridge towers, it is not a bad climb and has a reasonable fee. I found the museum to be fascinating as far as the history and technology of the bridge. For example, I am amazed that the towers exist solely for cosmetic purposes. How values change with time and place....

Superb view. Wow, what a breathtaking view. There are around 200 steps to get to this lookout but it is so worth it. The story of building the bridge is told through storyboards as you make your way up. However the view is the star and with a harbour that glistens like a gemstone it can only be spectacular. It cost $11 to climb up but is a great alternative to those unable to climb the bridge itself. The high glass surounding the lookout makes you feel very safe. I'm terrified of heights but had no problems here at all. It is a bit tricky to find but if you find the bridge walk entrance you'll find the friendly staff happily pointing you in the right direction (about 150m to the left, haha). I highly recommend this to all.

What a LOOKOUT. This is a great way to view Sydney Harbour at far less of a cost compared to the Bridge Climb. If you don't have the money for Bridge Climb I highly recommend this. You have the option of watching a short film on the history of the bridge and once on the top you will have 360 degree views of Sydney Harbour in all its glory.

hidden gem!!. Why is this attraction not more well publicised by Sydney Tourist Board? We even spoke to locals who knew nothing of its existence. Great 36 deg views from the top.$11 each and that includes a film show and pictorial story board of how the bridge was built. Excellent!

Definately worth doing. My husbnad and i did this on our recent trip to sydney.we got the train to milsons point,then walked across the harbour bridge and did the pylon lookout on the way across.it was amazing.fantastic views of the city and all the big attractions.cost roughly $22 but was worth it.

Cheap bridge climb. It was about AUD10.00 for the climb up the stairs of the Sydney pylon, which provides a breath taking view of the bridge and the harbor. You can also see the people on the bridge climb. After descending take the stirs to the bottom of the bridge and stop off at one of the pubs for a cold beer.

A great alternative to the bridge walk. We wanted to get a good view of Sydney from the bridge but the price of the bridge walk was a bit too expensive and you're not allowed to take your camera up with you so I saw this as an alternative to doing the bridge walk and at $11 a ticket it was a much better for our budget.
