There are 222 stairs up once you go up onto the bridges' road level, but there's plenty of rest places and exhibits so you can take your time. It is signposted around the city so you can find it. The views from the top are fantastic of the harbor and the opera house, and if you know someone on the bridge walk you could take photos of them from the top quite easily. It wasn't very busy when we went up but that could be because it was winter.
great veiw. nothing to dislike make sure you get a clear day with not much wind around $25.00 great veiw a bit of a walk but worth it

Worth the walk. Nice little walk to a pleasant surprise. Not only do you learn the history of the bridge, the viewing deck offers fantastic views of the harbor and the famous Opera House. A must do if you're in the area.

Best thign i have ever done!. I actually did the full walk over the harbour bridge which took 3 hours with all the talk first and explanations on what to do, was the best experience ever and I would definitely do it again if I was in Sydney again, I don't like heights but I did it and you don't even notice how high you are up!!!

Great view of the harbour for a fraction of the cost of a BridgeClimb. For just $12.50 you not only get a spectacular view of the harbour just slightly below the height of the top of the arch. There is also a great museum detailing the building of the bridge. Access is from the walkway across the bridge so a great opportunity to walk the bridge as well.

Save the big money for a meal up Sydney Tower. Do we rope up and do the Bridge climb or do we spend 11 dollars to climb the pylon, take our own photos, then use the difference for a meal up the revolving restaurant? If you have unlimited funds, do it all - the bridge climb looks ok, if a bit slow. We chose to fund the revolving meal and don't regret it!
Very informative venue. Loved reading the history and got some wonderful photos. The video was interesting and the stained glass windows were amazing. Great views of the city.

Great way to see the harbour if not able to climb the bridge. Loved it. Was great way to feel like you were getting the same view as if you climbed the bridge itself. Of course not as good as the real thing but cost effective if you cant afford the bridge climb.
Amazingly Beautuful view. Get an amazing view of the Harbour bridge and its structure as well as the traffic flowing on the bridge. Must go for the view!

The best and cheapest 360 degrees view of Sydney Harbour. Sydney Harbour Bridge Pylon Lookout offers one of the finest 360 degrees views over the city and its magnificent Opera House.It is a Must Do when in Sydney.The 200 stairs that take you to the top of the pylon (87m above sea level) are easily climbed and the reward once at the top is a splendid view of the city and its surrounding.The access to the pylon is located directly on the bridge’s pedestrian walkway and the first flights of steps lead straight to the ticket office.The climb will then take you through various rooms were a lot of memorabilia and photos retrace the construction of the bridge.You will also find mannequins representing workers and maintenance teams who were involved in the construction of the structure.The upper level of the tower has more memorabilia and photos retracing the history of the bridge.The view that you obtain from the top platform is absolutely phenomenal as it directly overlooks the Rocks, and the Opera House on the next bay.It is one of the most beautiful scenes if you happen to be there on a bright sunny day as we were!It is pure beauty!As you climbed down towards the exit you will come across a smaller room located next to the ticket office where original clothes, tools etc… have been gathered.I guess we could call it a small “museum”.It links to another larger room where a huge screen shows every 5mn a film retracing the history of the bridge from its conception, construction and maintenance.The film is very comprehensive and fascinating as we discover the faces of the people who were involved in the project.It also shows the various steps of the construction and we can only admire the feat of engineering along with the drive and passion of all those who proudly participated to the bridge’s erection.The visit costs 10AUD per adult and if I remember well half price for students.The money raise is mainly reused for the maintenance of the bridge as such a beautiful structure needs constant checks.This visit is far less expensive than the climbing of the bridge (about 200AUD and a different type of experience though) and is a perfect alternative for those who want to have a great view of Sydney Harbour without paying a fortune.I would obviously not recommend this climb to people with health issues or physical disability because of the stairs.

Heaps of steps but worth the effort!. My friend suggested I see Sydney from the top of the pylon of the Sydney Harbour Beidge. He told me there were a few steps to climb. Boy did he underestimate haha. I think there were around 230 steps to climb, they kept coming and coming. Finally with legs feeling like jelly, i made it to the top. Yay!He was right. Nthe view is amazing. The cost for the climb was about $11. We took fantastic photos of the harbour and Milsons Point and the Opee House.Can be a bit tricky to find the pylon...I just followed my leader lol.It's a great alternative to the Bridge Climb at a fraction of the cost if it's just the view you are after rather than the climb experience.Be prepares for stiff legs the following day but truly is worth the effort. Recuperate at one of the local pubs around The Rocks afterward with a cool amber to.reward yourself!!!

Great experience. There are quite a lot of stairs to tread on the way up but there are landings where you can stop and spend time looking at the interesting exhibits and photos of various aspects, plus historical notes, etc. about the Sydney Harbour Bridge and its planning, building, etc. When you get to the top the view is fabulous!! The visit and views are just about as good as the "Bridge Climb" without the nervousness and fear many would feel! - And certainly less expensive.
Budget alternative to bridge climb. $11 per person to see the best views of sydney. The 200 steps could be hard going if you aren't very fit but are well worth the trek to the top!

well worth it. Great, really worth it. Is only $11 and you get great views from the top. is a bit of a walk but there is stops on the way up and down where you can read about facts from when the bridge was being built, all the how, whys and so on.

Fantastic views. A great alternative to climbing the bridge at a fraction of the cost. The entrance fee is minimal and inside is a small but interesting museum. But up the top is what you pay the fee for and that's the all round views of sydney harbour. Great photo opportunities.

Wonderful View. Even if you don’t do the bridge climb, make sure you go to the pylon lookout and museum. The views are wonderful. Continue on over the bridge to Kirribilli and you will find a couple of good café’s and a bakehouse for a coffee or a meal.

A must do when in Sydney. Even if you don’t do the bridge climb, make sure you go to the pylon lookout and museum. The views are wonderful. Continue on over the bridge to Kirribilli and you will find a couple of good café’s and a bakehouse for a coffee or a meal.

Bridge Climb alternative. The Sydney Harbour Bridge climb is the rock star, I did it with my husband and two friends from the US who thought it was great. I'd recommend the dusk booking as you get to see day and night views and the sunset on a good day. But there's a little known alternative that's much easier and cheaper - The SHB Pylon Lookout, open 7 days 10-5pm. You can take the elevator or the stairs, it includes a museum about the bridge and it costs just $11 (less with concession) to enter! It's in the north-east pylon of the bridge. The four brick pylons of the bridge are decorative only, few visitors know you can get the same view on top of this one pylon as you do on top of the bridge, just maybe half as high. And there's more good news, unlike the Bridge climb, who usually don't let you change the time and date of your climb once ticketed, you can go to the pylon any day it's open and buy your ticket when it suits you. The bridge climb takes about 2 hours to get suited, briefed and do the climb, and it's not great for seniors or kids for obvious reasons, it's expensive, non refundable or changeable even if the weather is the motivation and you can't take anything up there, including cameras so you have to buy the shots they take. The Pylon Lookout is suitable for all ages and visitors so I always suggest the pylon alternative unless you're really hung up on climbing to the top of the span of the bridge.

Fantastic cheap activity on a clear day. Forget the BridgeClimb, walk up the Southern Pillon and learn about the history of "the coat hanger" for a fraction of the price. I have done this trip numerous times over the years, and on a clear day the views are spectacular. Bring some water and snacks for the kids as the shops around both ends of the brige are pricey.
interesting. good to see the history of the Bridge and must do the Bridge walk . its something special, very safe, well worth the money, then have lunch at the rocks , heaps of places to pick from

Sydney Harbour Bridge. The Bridge offers visitors a great variety of ways to see and remember the experience. A ferry ride on Sydney Harbour offers views of the Bridge, its height, span and majestical appearance against the backdrop of the city. A visit to the South East Pylon where for a small sum you can climb the to the Pylon Lookout and take in the views around the Harbour as well as an end on view of the Bridge construction. Walk the bridge by the pedestrian path or pay to climb up the bridge is the other alternatives to taking in this great feature, but for me a ride on the Harbour allows you to capture the true beauty of this Sydney feature attraction.
Great view. If you haven't got time for the bridge climb this is a good option, good views and a very interesting museum about the building of the bridge.

The Sydney harbour Bridge. The Sydney Harbour Bridge has a viewing tower on the south eastern Sandstone Pylon which is open to visitors for around $9.50 The view of Sydney Harbour is beutiful from this position. There is interesting information inside the Pylon about how the bridge was contructed. I highly recommend this attraction to anyone.

A much cheaper option than Bridge climb and almost as spectacular. From the rocks climb up the stairs to the Harbour Bridge and walk to the first pylon. Pay a minimal fee and walk up the stairs to the viewing platform. Here you will enjoy amazing views, at a fraction of the price of Bridge Climb.

Mind blowing. The harbour bridge is every thing you would expect it to be. This iconic symbol of Sydney is an amazing feat of early 19th century engineering.We had discussed walking the bridge but at £120 each we decided not to do it. There is an slightly less arduous way of seeing the same view though. One of he pylons at each end has a museum that explains how they built the bridge and at the top of that is a look out platform which gives you the same view of he harbour but slightly lower. That costs 11 dollars which is vastly different. Still worth walking the bridge if you want to though.

Stunning and won't disappoint. Visiting with my ten year old son, we discovered the Pylon Lookout climb and followed this with a walk across the Bridge. No need for expensive commercial activities such as the Bridge Climb, yo can walk across the bridge for free, enjoying to sights and views at you leisure. When you get across its only a short ride back to the city on one of the numerous trains that cross over and stop a the nearby station across the bridge. Not to be missed!

Not to be missed!. A less glamourous alternative to the very expensive Sydney Harbour Bridge climb, this activity is not to be missed.i visited with my ten year old son, and it was a fantastic experience for both of us. Easily accessible from The Rocks or Circular Quay area (tip: access is from the Bridge level, not down below at the very base of the Pylon), after a short climb, about 200 steps you are at about 90m altitude looking out over the bridge and beautiful Sydney harbour (that's like being on the top floor of a 25 story building) - stunning views. Although we were there mid-morning, we had the observation deck virtually to ourselves to enjoy in peace. And admission is great value, and only a fraction of the more expensive commercial walk.After the Pylon Climb you can walk across the bridge enjoying the sights and view, to the rail station on the other side and catch a train back to Circular Quay.

Great value and alternative to bridge climb. OK, here's the deal. My wife and I visited Sydney during June 2013. I'm a engineer, nerd, and love history of such things as this. And I am also not overly excited of heights or climbing over bridges. My wife? definitely not a nerd or into these things like me. She is, however, into the thrill of climbing, and adventure. We "compromised" (my word, not her's) to do the pylon lookout instead of the bridge climb. Turned out to be a great option for us. It is much cheaper ($11 per person vs a couple hundred), is much quicker (30-60 minute tour vs 4 hrs), and takes you to reasonably similar heights over the Harbor. Also the pylon gives you a museum tour with history and educational items about the bridge construction (I don't know if you get those on the bridge climb). My wife enjoyed this option, it was far cheaper, much quicker and self guided, and you get a great view. If you just gotta climb the bridge, go ahead. If you want a positive alternative, here you go... And for those that cant seem to find this option..its in the pylon closest to the opera house. Find the stairway up to the bridge itself, and you enter the pylon from the sideway off the bridge...not from the base down bay the edge of the bay..Approx 100 steps to the top.
Great view!. The view from this lookout is one of the most amazing views you can get, as it gives you a great view of Sydney Harbor, my favorite harbor in the world! Not to be missed!!

Great value for money. One of the must things to do while in Sydney. Although it is a little hard to locate. For 11 dollars it is worth the money to learn the history of the Harbour Bridge. There also is about 200 stairs to go up but honestly it is worth it at the end, the view is amazing. I took like 100 photos and just didn't want to leave.

???????. ??????$400?bridge climbing, ????$11???????.????30????????.??17:00??????.????the rocks!
Consider paying $400 for bridge climbing, rather suggest pylon lookout for elderly and children, it's far more affordable (i. e. $11), and you can stay as long as you deserved, nothing is too rush like bridge climbing.
Great place for History and Views. Be aware there is a few stairs to go up, but the history and views are worth a visit. Got some great photo's of the Harbour and Bridge from here.

Hidden gem. Fantastic way of learning about the history of the Harbour Bridge without paying all the money for the Bridge Climb. $11 for adults and $6.50 for kids. Great value and not crowded on the day we went. Fantastic views.

Great view from the Sydney Bridge!. Outstanding photo opportunities of downtown Sydney and the Opera House... Only $11 for adults. They say there are 100 steps but if you take them two at a time, there is really only 50!

Harbour Bridge climb views (without so much of the 'climb'). I recently took my in-laws for a bit of a tourist day out around Sydney. They had never been to Sydney. One of my favourite things to do with people to help them get their bearings is to go on a walk through The Rocks (this sets the scene nicely), and then up onto the Harbour Bridge pathway going north.As you walk up through the Rocks you pass many local attractions that really make you feel you've arrived in Sydney. From Circular Quay, pass the MCA. Then walk up Argyle cut. Just before the underpass there are some 'ancient' stairs through an archway to your right. walk up these. They are old, originally cut by convicts I think. At the top of the stairs turn left and follow the pathway around behind the local pub, The Glenmore Hotel. As a side note you can stop here on your way back and enjoy a beer. It's a great spot for a light bite too. Cross the road and head up another set of steps onto the Harbour Bridge walkway. Don't forget your camera. As you walk along the pathway heading northbound toward the bridge you get glimpses of views down into The Rocks and eastward to the Opera House and beyond. It's just exhilarating to see people's faces when they see the harbour for the first time. But don't stop there. Carry on toward the harbour bridge until you get to the Harbour Bridge Pylon. This is the gigantic pillar made of steel and stonework. You'll find the entrance to the Pylon Lookout here. Now, before I go on, please be aware there are stairs. If you've recently had knee surgery don't push yourself. There are some 100+ steps to climb. There are floors along the way at different levels. On each level is either an exhibition about the bridge build or indicators about the views at the top.The Pylon Lookout is $15 per adult to visit. Considering you climb to where the bridge climbers go to and pay $150+ for the privilege I think the Pylon Lookout is well worth the money. It's well worth the climb up the steps to the top. Even if you are nervous about heights. Once you reach the viewing area you can walk around the whole pylon in safety. Everywhere you look there are sights to see. Looking west The Blue Mountains can be seen in the distance. Homebush and the Olympic park closer to the city. The Parramatta river becomes Sydney Harbour at Gladesville bridge. The inner west meets the city at Anzac Bridge, just infront of Balmain and the inner harbour islands called Cockatoo and Goat. To the south you see the Royal National Park in the distance. Australia's first national park reserve. Of course right in front of you there is the city and many iconic buildings. To the east you can see the main part of the harbour, circular quay, the opera house. Right the way to Watsons Bay in the distance and around to the entrance to the harbour. To the north is, well The Bridge itself. Then the lower north shore suburbs. All in all on any day this is a brisk afternoon out. The whole walk from The Glenmore, up onto the Bridge and Pylon Lookout, and back will probably take about 1.5 hrs to 2 hours depending on your pace. You could walk right over the bridge to Kirribilli and Milsons Point too. Then catch a ferry back to Circular Quay or Darling Harbour. Hope you enjoy my review and enjoy the outing even more. And don't forget to stop for a brew at The Glenmore Hotel or Australian Hotel on your way back down from the Pylon Lookout. You will have earned it.

Pylon Lookout. After standing back and taking probably between 50 to a 100 photos of the bridge we decided to climb the pylon to the lookout and take in the views from the top. You get a wonderful view of all around the Harbor and on the way up there are displays and stories of the building of the bridge. If your not up to doing a bridge climb this is an easy option to still get some really good views and an understanding of the efforts that went into building this fantastic object.

Beautiful View of Sydney. We walked for about 10 minutes on the harbor bridge to reach the pylon lookout. it says 200 stairs but frankly it not that tiring and before you even notice your at the top. the $11 is well worth it and while you walk towards the top the history of the bridge is displayed at each level. The view from the top is spectacular.. you can see the opera house and the bridge.. We saw a few people climbing the bridge from our vantage point. the tower gives you a 360 degree view of the city so you can walk around and check it from all angles. once your done and just before the exit, there is a short movie that plays out the making of the bridge and important people who played a part in the construction of this historic bridge. Well worth it..

Pylon. 200 steps but you hardly notice them, great views from the top. $11 well worth it! Walk along the harbour bridge to north Sydney from rocks, and pylon entrance is at the start of the bridge ' proper' we had trouble finding it. Thought it was near the bridge walk...it soooo isn't!

Hidden gem in plain sight. We were in The Rocks in Sydney and with a bit of time to spare, we decided to find the Pylon Lookout. I wouldn't recommend it if you have difficulty with stairs because there are quite a few from Cumberland St to reach the Bridge footway and then the sign says there are 200 stairs to the top level. If one flight of stairs is manageable for you, then this lookout could be reached by taking your time as there are spots to rest at the top of each flight, and displays of interesting information as well.I didn't think it was hard to find, it's in the south east pylon of the Harbour Bridge, but we did know the way up from The Rocks. An hour in the Pylon is probably enough and allow another 20mins to get to and from.It costs $11 dollars per adult which we thought was extremely good value.
Great views. A great much cheaper alternative to the bridge climb. Fantastic views of the city and the Opera House and Harbour.

Must see!. A little hard to locate but fabulous views! History of the Harbour Bridge displayed as you walk up the stairs (quite a few stairs)! Amazing view over Sydney at the top, but it can be a bit crowded!
Walk up the pylon. We walked the 200 steps to the top of the pylon which was good value for 11 dollars, great views all around the top and a nice little museum about the construction of the bridge

Can't Miss Views!. While the entrance to the lookout is a little tricky to locate (it's off of Argyle street in the Rocks), this place is a definite must-see! The views from the top are incredible (both of the Harbour Bridge and of the Opera House)! The climb up is not bad at all (about 200 stairs), and as you go up, most of the landings hold little museum exhibits with intersting facts about the history of the bridge and its construction. I would say you get some of the same views from the top as the bridge climb, and at a MUCH cheaper price ($11). I would recommend this to anyone visiting Sydney!

Don't miss this gem. Not as good as the walk over the top (which has become rather expensive) but the pylon provides sensational views of the Harbour and a detailed history of the building of the Bridge. A must do attraction!

A Different Angle. I agree ,if you are less mobile walk up the stairs in the Pylon for a great view. and the Museum of how the bridge was built.Next to the bridge access stairs fromThe Rocks side, walk up the ramp through to The Observatory and view the bridge from a beautiful lookout and a park full of spectacular Fig trees.Also walk down under the bridge on both sides of the harbour and admire the massive stonework built to support the bridge. Under is just as impressive as over so be sure to see the whole package! Maurice B

Best kept Secret in Sydney.. Not many people I know realise the Pylon Lookout is open to the public. It is great value and you have beautiful views of Sydney Harbour and the Opera House.. There is a small museum in the Pylon. This is a fraction of the cost of the Sydney Harbour Bridge Walk and you can see the walkers on the Bridge. A must do for locals and tourists. There are quite a few steps to the top. Access is via the southern walkway on The Rocks side of the bridge.

Better than the bridge climb. More than 10x times cheaper and you can take your own photos at will, while learning about the construction of the bridge. Not essential tho, you can still take great photos from the bridge just by walking on it and that is free.
Incredible. My wife and I did the Pylon Climb, and not the bridge climb. You can get some incredible views for $11 each, rather than the $200 each to do the bridge climb.

Nice views over Sydney Harbour. I happen to have a fear of depths, and therefore I would never clime Sydney Harbour Bridge. Although it is a totally different kind of thing, the Pylon Lookout brings you almost as high as the top of the bridge (ok, almost ;) ) but still with the safe feeling of the solid rock around you. Inside there is an exhibition about building the bridge, which is compact but very informative. The walk up is an easy one, so doable for everyone. A must do if you visit Sydney.
Pylon Lookout. Great views from the lookout - cost was only $11 AUS per adult and gives an interesting history of the bridge as well as the opportunity to take photos of the opera house, harbour etc.
Walk for $11 AUD. No need to do the Bridge climb. Just walk up to the first pylon after 10 am and you can walk up the pylon and get all the sights for a fraction of the cost.

Sydney Harbour Bridge, South East Pylon Meseum and Views. If you want the views from Sydney Harbour Bridge, but don't want to do the bridge climb over the top (which is expensive, and not possible with children under 10) it's well worth walking up inside the SE Pylon. The museam within the plyon is small but informative, and the views from the top are great. The stairs inside the pylon are normal stairs and fine for childen - though there are quite a lot of steps! The outdoor viewing area is open to the elements but safe, and there are steps for children to stand on so they can see over the wall. The only problem is finding the entrance - you can't access it from under the bridge, you need to walk on the footpath beside the road on the bridge level to get to the entrance.

South East Pylon - don't miss it!. If you want excellent views across Sydney without the expense and 'thrill' of the bridge climb, then head for the South East Pylon. It's not advertised, but the Tourist Info will point you in the right direction. You go up several flights of stairs via an informative museum and out to the top walkway around the pylon. It's cheap and great value - highly recommended!

Amazing. The bridge in it self is beautiful. Climb one off the pillars close to "The Rock" , save a lot off money and make your own pictures. The bridge climb itself is very expensive, and you are not allowed to make pictures. The view from the pillars is as well stunning.

Great. I decided i had to go up here as im too scared of heights to climb the bridge. it was hard going up as you could see down the stairs, but very glad i did when i got to the top, view was fantasic.

Worth the climb. We got a bit lost trying to find the entrance to the Pylon walk, the signage could be improved, but this attraction is worth hunting out.I am a bit phobic about heights so no way would I do the bridge climb but this gives you terrific views over Sydney without the fear factor. The 200 steps are not too difficult and there are displays along the way to enjoy. But the photo ops from the top are the best - a 360 degree view over Sydney, a different angle for pics of the Opera House and close up views of the bridge with the climbers in action too.The videos shown in the room before the exit are great too.Well worth the entrance fee of about $12.

a look at the construction of sydney harbour bridge. a great few hours spent here looking at photos and reading about the construction of the sydney harbour bridge. some good views also . worth a visit after climbing the bridge, so close by.

Fantastic Photo Opportunity!. This is probably the best way to view the city, for the money. The 200 steps are not that much of a problem for most people, and the sight from the top of the pylon is amazing! I took most of my best shots of Sydney from up here.

Great views. The view is awesome and well priced for what you get. There is a good collection of memorabillia and the history of the bridge as you go up. Great photo op of the Opera House and up Sydney Harbour. Next best thing to bridge climb and a couple of great pubs at the entrance. Don't miss the rooftop beer garden at the Glenmore Pub or the Burrogorang Bock at the Australian Hotel.

Amazing structure in stunning location. I'm too wimpy to do the bridge climb. If you're like me the best option is to go up the Southern Pillon instead. The entry fee is small and there's a neat museum at the top. The big plus is the awesome view. You get most of what the bridge climbers get for a fraction of the price! Also the walk across the bridge is a must do. Once there it's easy to jump on a train at Milson's Point and head back to the city.
Awe inspiring. Everything about the bridge is fascinating. The South Pylon climb is fabulous and historically rich. It is hard to imagine the perils of constructing this structure.

Didn't do the bridge climb, but did go to the pylon lookout. The Sydney harbour bridge is another icon that you think of when you think of Sydney. To climb the bridge is really expensive and it is my understanding that you can not take a camera. You can walk/run across the bridge for free and I suggest that you do. There is a small park on the other side of the bridge that gives you a different view of the city and opera house which is worth the walk. You can also climb to the top of the pylon lookout which we did. I am not sure of the cost to do this, as our hotel gave us a voucher. The pylon lookout was nice and gave you a good view and you can use your camera there. Something to consider if you don't want to spend the money to climb to the top of the bridge.

amazing views for an affordable price. I've done the Sydney Bridge Climb, and it was so worth the cost and effort for the views. On this visit I decided to do the Pylon Lookout instead because I wanted to take my own photos. It's a lot of steps to the top, but the award is worth every tiring step. I didn't bother so much with the displays or video so can't comment on them, I went just for the view and photo ops, neither of which disappointed. AWESOME! I love being able to see all the way to the Blue Mountains and all the way to the Pacific Ocean. Take a look down too and you can see the famous car with the boulder in the middle of it. Take your time to just look out and see, I spent an hour and a half just thinking about how Sydney probably looked before the bridge and Opera House were built, but to each his or her own.

Do it at least once!!. In 1956, after we'd migrated to Australia and found ourselves in Sydney, one of the first things we did was visit this pylon lookout. I signed the guestbook, as a 12 year old. I've also supervised school excursions there. Small or large group. All very good!

...great views!. this was what i expected it to be! flights of stairs with floors of information about the bridge, and an extreamly over priced gift shop. they should really build a lift cause i could imagine people turning away! good views once youre up but there's alot better!
Amazing Views. A must do, the views are amazing. Took some of my favourite panoramic pictures up there. Not too expensive either.

Excellent option if you have kids!. We did this with two young children as unable to do the bridge climb - view is amazing and price is very good. Nice to then walk to the opera house looking back at the bridge and to say we've just been up there !

Excellent substitue for the bridge climb. I looked at the bridge climb and it was super expensive, so I decided to climb the look out tower instead. It's a climb, but great views from the top. At only $11 it is good value for money, though the video could use some work. It is artfully put together with great music, but has no narration, and so you are left guessing what it is all about.
Excellent Views and Great Value. You get great views of the brige and the Rocks and harbour area. There is interesting exhibitions to look at about the building of the bridge.

Great views and Sydney Harbour Bridge museum. We enjoyed watching the BridgeClimbers, loved the view of the harbour, and found the museum about the building of the Bridge fascinating. Yes, it is more expensive than it used to be in the 80s (isn't everything?) but the museum has been greatly improved. I think it cost our family of four $30 and was about the best thing we did in Sydney. Better value than $90 for a tour of the Opera House, and the Bridge is equally as famous and has a more interesting history.

Has to be done!. When we told our friends we were travelling to Sydney everyone asked whether we were planning to climb the bridge. Well, no - we didn't. We chose to climb the Pylon, which is a minute fraction of the cost of the full climb, has views almost as good. (so we were told) and only involves climbing 200 steps.The Bridge is iconic - but the museum displays within the Pylon show it's significance as a statement for the Australian people as well as it's role in keeping the Sydney economy afloat following the Depression of the 1930's.Climbing the Pylon - recommended!

Climb the Pylon if you don't want the full climb. We didn't want to climb the bridge (age and cost!) but decided on the Pylon Lookout. Brilliant views and possibly better than the Climb as you get to take your own camera. Nice little exhibition on the way up.

Too chicken to go up!. Saw all the brave souls do the climb, went to the visitors centre, chickened out, then took the time to do the museum behind the admissions counter. Learned a lot about the construction, the history and the hardships people went though to get this amazing piece of engineering done.

$$$s Take Over. What used to be an affordable look over the harbour from the bridge pylon, now attacks your pocket to the equivalent of £10 or so.What a shame and what a loss to Tourism Sydney.The Bridge walk is great, a pity that the Pylon is now pricing itself out of the equation. The 'Over The Harbour Bridge' walk too is outrageous it now is over £100.00 per person.Tourism suffers generally of this type of pricing.

Pylon Lookout. Pylon Lookout is not a bad place to go and get a really good view of the Sydney Harbour, especially if you are not game enough (like me) to go on that bridge climb - I would recommend it to anyway.

Two thirds of the height for 5% of the cost!. If time and / or money are an issue than the Pylon Lookout is for you. Check web site www.pylonlookout.com.au/ for times and prices. Just be prepared for 200 stairs. Plenty of places to stop and rest as well.AND you get to take ALL the pictures you want (you can't take any on the Bridge Climb) and spend as LONG as you want (within the opening hours).

Fantastic View. This was free after doing the bridge climb, and I'm so glad we did it. Had we not done the bridge climb we probably would have missed this gem. The real perk here is you can take your own camera up with you, unlike the bridge climb. You aren't as high up as when you do the climb, but the view is still incredible. I think the price is about $11 per person, which makes it easily worth while for anyone who doesn't want to shell out $200+ for the climb.

Well worth doing. At only $11, this place is virtually a bargain to visit. Heaps of things to read and bits of stuff to look at about this amazing bridge. Then, there is the great lookout point at the top of the pylon. Even if you have vertigo, this is easy to manage. You aren’t quite as high up as those doing the Bridge Walk, but at less than a 10th of the price, I recommend this to simply everybody!

A fantastic Sydney Point of view. Many Sydney visitors would like to do the famous Bridge Climb, but are put off by the cost or the physical effort. There is a more affordable alternative, the Pylon Lookout Climb which we did one sunny morning recently. From the steps off Argyle Street, in the lovely historic Rocks area, we walked along the footpath to the first Pylon, paid the modest ticket cost (A$8.50) and set off up the 200 steps. Each landing had a fascinating display of the design, building and workers who created this iconic city symbol.Finally at the top, we had the entire city spread out before us, with magnificent views over the harbour and Opera House,. the Gap and the bustling ferry boats. Below us toiled the Bridge climbers making their way to the highest point, and just across the way, in Circular quay, a magnificent cruise ship gleamed in the sun. We were able to stay as long as we wished, take many photos, and wend our way down unhurriedly, just in perfect time for a delicious lunch in one of the old Rocks pubs.

Unlike the Bridge Walk, You Can Take Your Camera!. The pylon lookout is a good and inexpensive alternative to the bridge walk, and the fact that cameras are allowed makes it arguably even better. There is an exhibition showing photos and plans of the building stages. There´s also a film on the bridge, which is very interesting. Concessions apply for everyone over 60, Aussie or not, proof not required (rare in Australia!).

Great views of Sydney from the Pylon Lookout. The museum is rather fascinating- it has a whole section on how the Sydney Harbour Bridge was constructed, the entire history, which was accompanied with photographs, and visual (virtual reality) footage.The pylon offers 360 degrees views of Sydney and some of its famous landmarks, such as Sydney Opera House, the Sydney Harbour Bridge, Circular Quay, etc.A small entrance fee applies -well worth a visit ! There is a small gift shop with selection of gifts available for purchase. Look at the posters.

Great views from the pylons. We were going to do the bridge walk but after seeing the price,~$210, we decied to go up the pylon, $15. I am guessing that the bridge walk is great but I would rather us that kind of money to skydive or bungee jump if I am looking for a thrill.There is a museum in the pylon that is very interesting and the views of the harbour from the top are fantastic. Well worth doing

Good workout for the legs. Climbed the 200 steps from the road deck to the top of the pylon - glad there were a couple of levels to stop at to take a breath. Interesting displays and good views from the top. Most staff helpful and friendly, one seemed a little disinterested in helping.

Icon of Sydney. One of the icons of Sydney is truly impressive as it straddles the Harbour. The climb is, although expensive, highly recommended (refer Bridgeclimb for reviews). Also recommend the climb up the South East pylon which has many historic photos of construction and interesting facts. The view from the top of the pylon is also fantastic - offering 360 degree views.
Worth a walk and Visit. a great walk with great views, visit the pylon museum for more views and history on the building of the bridge, with going to to indulge in this Sydney icon
S E Pylon. I walked up the South East Pylon and had some wonderful views as you can walk right round the top for a great scan of the harbour.

Great Views, be prepared for the Wind. We only walked up the Pylon but did not do the Bridge Climb, which takes you right up on top. Even on the Pylon, the wind was something to contend with. And 200 steps up did not come easy. But, the views were well worth the effort.

Unlike the bridge climb, you can take your camera. I thought this was a great alternative to the expensive bridge climb. The top of the support pylon gives a wonderful 360 degree view over the harbour. The history of the bridge is well illustrated. This is not a widely advertised attraction but if you walk over the bridge, as I would urge you to do, you will walk right past it.

A bridge with a view... My husband and I were honeymooning in Sydney and looking for fun activities that wouldn't use up our whole day's budget. The Pylon Lookout was a great substitute for us for the Bridge Climbing Experience. While we're adventurists and would have loved to strap on a harness and make our way up the longest single span arch bridge in the world, the cost of the Bridge Climb made it out of our reach. We settled for the Pylon Lookout and were pleasantly surprised! We were able to walk to the lookout from the The Rocks - just head toward the pylons. There's about 200 stairs you have to climb before you enter the exhibit, so be prepared to break a sweat. It was only $30 a person for our tickets, and it was much more interactive than we would would have imagined. I will warn that there are several flights of stairs headed up - thank goodness there was a water fountain halfway up because we had not brought anything to drink. We had our picture taken sitting on a ledge, as if we were sitting on the bridge before it was finished, and it made a nice souvenir. There were exhibits leading up to the pylon, both interesting and educational. When we fiinally reached the top, the view of Sydney is splendid. The harbour and sight of the Sydney opera house alone is enough to make you swoon. We spent a good half hour walking around, feeling the wind whip around us, and admiring the view. I loved reading about the making of the bridge in the room attached to the lookout, and learned how white cats have a special connection to the bridge. I would def recommend the Pylon Lookout for those who are not afraid of climbing lots of stairs!

Best view in sydney. Walk across the sydney harbour bridge and go up the south pylon to the museum and see how the bridge was built. If you have agoraphobia this is the one for you. Go to the top of the pylon and get 360 degree view of sydney without having to do the very expensive bridge climb. Amazing!!

Next best thing to the Bridgeclimb!. You climb up inside the pylon into a very informative museum dedicated to the building of the harbour bridge. The views from the lookout offer excellent photo opportunities. Finally there is a well made video presentation, worth sitting down for. If you don't have the chance to climb the bridge , this is a must.

Great Bridge. I walked across this bridge to the North and took the train back. You can go up the southern Pylon for $15. You get a good view from the top of one of the double decker carriages of Darling Harbor and the rest of the upper harbor.

Walking across the bridge a delight. I have never done the "bridge climb" but if you want a higher view than the roadway level, you can climb the south pylon if you don't mind the steps - there are levels with exhibitions if you need a rest. The best way to tackle the bridge if you're not too sprightly, is to catch the train to Milsons Point (1st station on the Luna Park side) and walk back over the bridge towards the Circular Quay/Opera House side. The views are spectacular and the bridge is never too crowded for a leisurely stroll. On the Quay side there are lots of cafes and restaurants to refresh yourself once you've taken the steps down the Argyle Cut.

Coathanger. Get the train to Milson's point and walk back over the bridge for spectacular views of the city and the harbour. Why pay $200 to do the bridge climb, when, for $15, you can do the Bridge Museum in the South East pylon. The viewing deck takes you three-fifths of the way up the bridge for less than a tenth of the cost. This is one of Sydney's hidden bargain gems.
Amazing!. Even if you can't afford the $200 to walk over the top of the bridge or you don't have the head for heights there is a smaller walk for $15 up a tower and the sights are just as good.

If on a budget- the pylon climb is a fine alternative!. I know we are all supposed to climb the bridge, and I certainly think it must be worth the raves. BUT I think the price is highway(pun intended) robbery. I mean, this is beyond the reach of many people, including my family, and someone is making jillions on this.However, do not despair! if you don't have the extra thousand dollars for the 4 of you to hike the bridge without being allowed your camera, and the privilege of purchasing a photo for a small( relatively) extra fee, you can go up the 200 steps inside the southwest pylon for only $12 AD! Such a deal! The only cheap thing in Sydney! And a photo of your party superimposed over a bridge background is included! You also can bring your camera and snap away to your hearts content.The views are excellent, and we went right at opening time on a Friday, so we really had the place almost entirely to ourselves. Then we spent our extra thousand dollars on a rental car, 2 nights in a cottage, and a sumptuous wine tour in the Hunter Valley, and still had money left over.....

Bridge Climb on a budget!. We recently had some free time in Sydney and decided upon visiting the Pylon Lookout. I have done the Bridge Climb but for $15 the Pylon Lookout is reasonably priced and a great way to see the views of Sydney Harbour.

Pylon Walk. Didn't think as"oldies" we would do the Bridge Walk so just did the Pylon Climb. That was well worth the effort as the day was a sparkling blue and clear and the scenery was spectacular. Being able to get the 360 deg photos was a bonus. But I think next time it will be the bridge walk as the groups that we watched seemed to be doing it at a reasonable pace.
Avoid paying $300 dollars and go up the pylon !. Great views for $15 from the pylon platform - only 200 steps and whilst not having the cache of the bridge walk it is a brilliant alternative.

Do the Pylon $15 not the bridge climb - fantastic. Did you know you can go up the brick pylon to 90metres and see almost all the same stuff as $280 bridge climb (3.5hours).do it quick or take your time. interesting facts as well as cheap souvenirs and all views with your own camera.

Spectacular views and fascinating history of the bridge. Easy to find and access. Well worth the climb of the 200+ stairs for the spectacular views (photos galore). A good alternative to the Bridge Climb and only $15. Enjoyed the history lesson and displays too and the fact we could do it all at our own pace was great.

Pylon Climb. Great value for money, but hard to get to on foot. It was a very windy day which made it interesting, but the view from up there was amazing. With the cost of a bridge climb at $218 p/p, this is a great alternative at $15 p/p.

Pylon Lookout. We opted for the more budget friendly Pylon Lookout climb over the bridge climb. We could control the amount of time we spent (the bridge climb is about three hours), spent a good deal less money, and could take as many pictures as we desired (you can't take your camera or phone with you on the bridge climb for obvious reasons). Fantastic views... which we got to record with our own cameras... which I'm sure the Bridge Climb would have been an extra cost for any photos.

Great value for money!. For $15 this is a fantastic way to get to see the bridge and enjoy fabulous views of Sydney Harbour. We spent just over an hour here and apart from learning a lot about the bridge the scenery is amazing.

Unexpectedly fantastic. I remember climbing the bridge pylon some years ago, and took my daughter recently. What a fantastic surprise! It now has really great interpretation which we thoroughly enjoyed, telling the story of the construction and opening of the bridge - photos, a film, displays of memorabilia and object associated with the construction and bridge opening. The displays were very good - quick "sound bites" for people who want the once over lightly,and more detail for those who want it.A superb view in all four directions, not very bus when we were there,and so we could spend lots of time just gazing at the view.Probably not as spectacular as the bridge climb (as other reviewers have noted) but far cheaper and far more accessible!

Up front and from a distance. The bridge climb is exciting and there is great view from the top. The climb to the top of the southern pylon is a quicker and less expensive alternative. I enjoy the bridge in its own right and as a backdrop to the Opera House.

One alternative to see Sydney from height.. Interesting building and history, nice view outside, just need to make sure you have extra energy to climb the stairs, not that bad though, still good sightseeing.

Gorgeous Views from the Top, or Not!. My husband & I have walked across the Sydney Harbour Bridge several times in the five weeks we spent here. We had planned to participate in the climb to the top, but in talking with the concierge at our hotel decided it really was a lot to spend when we could go up in the Pylon for so much less($268+ compared to $14!). We decided that was just not necessary for us. That being said, I understand insurance, equipment, etc all has to be paid for, so, if you want to take part, it's up to you. Just be aware, the Pylon is about halfway up as far as the Bridge & you get great views from there as well. Views from the bridge are AWESOME, even if you are just walking!! Honestly, the views ANYWHERE around the harbour are so beautiful, don't feel pressured to pay such a huge fee to walk to the top of the bridge; that's the point I wanted to make. Sydneysiders have a wonderful treasure here.

Fantastic View at Budget Price. From the Pylon we had an amazing view of Sydney Harbour at a very low price which included a photo, there was a very interesting display of work in progress and facts. The only problem was the directions and the information outside the Pylon entrance. We found that from The Rocks following the signs to the Bridgewalk would get you in the right area and eventually give you a specific sigh to the Pylon Lookout. Once outside the entrance there was no information relating to openning times or clear clarification you are in the right place. This obviously not a problem if is open when you arrive, but as we were a little early was an issue.

The VIEW!!!!. First and foremost. Not the place for young kids who don't like walking up stairs.But for those who walk the stairs, the view is (withouta doubt) the best in Sydney Harbour. It is unrivalled.We've been here a number of times and for anyone visiting Sydney, we tell them to check it out.Australia Day 2010 we were on top of the pylon for the celebrations.... awesome day and awesome place!

Classic viewpoint. For those who prefer not to do the Bridge Climb, the Pylon is an outstanding place to stand a enjoy the classic Sydney Harbour view. Thanks to the movement of ships, the view is changing all the time and I took dozens of classic Sydney Harbour/Opera House shots.The Pylon is also a good place to observe the Sydney Harbour Bridge up close and even the 'bridge climbers'.By Sydney standards, the price was not too bad.
Pylon Lookout. Great views from the pylon lookout! Absolutely beautiful city

Pylon Better than Bridge climb!. I went on the Pylon lookout after a friend had done the Bridge climb and she was given two passes to the pylon. We walked the same staircase that the bridge climbers go up I believe, but stopped off and went onto the pylon. It was an absolute spectacular view of the bridge, Opera House, and a small glass window around the perimeter of the pylon with different cities' locations. The best plus for the pylon was the ability for you to take pictures with your own camera however you want. You didn't have to pay a fortune for the photos taken on the bridge climb with maybe some people you don't know. The views are obviously from a lower platform but its not that big of a difference and everything can still be seen perfectly. I loved it.

Good, but doesn't compare at all to Bridgeclimb!. Some people have said that the pylon lookout is just as good as Bridgeclimb - none had done Bridgeclimb though! We did both in Sydney and although the pylon lookout is good, with a nice exhibition and good views from the top, it just doesn't compare to the Bridgeclimb for views or adrenalin rush. Yes, it is a lot cheaper, so if you are on a budget too tight to do the Bridgeclimb then do go up the pylon.

Superb. We recently had a visitor to Sydney and its a bit of a dismal drizzly day, so we decided to have a walk across the Harbour Bridge and go to the Pylon Lookout - Much less than the Bridge Climb and your only have the height below!I must confess i had done this before a couple of years ago, but I still really enjoyed it and our antipodean visitor LOVED it!!!Recommended for all ages, if stairs are a struggle for you - just take your time!!

Amazing view at affordable rates. Pylon Lookout is a much more affordable alternative to the Sydney Harbour Bridge Clim. This is a place to visit to get fantastic views of the city and Sydney harbour from the iconic Harbour Bridge.Here's a tip, I find that it is easier to find my way to the Pylon Lookout if I were to head to Cumberland Street, the Rocks, from Wynyard train station (than Circular Quay train station). Please walk along the pedestrain pathway on the Eastern side of the Harbour Bridge for better views on your way to the Pylon Lookout.There are interesting exhibitis at Pylon Lookout that provides the history of the Harbour Bridge and more. It would take about 1 - 2 hours to enjoy the various exhibits. Remember to take a look at the exhibit on the early plywood model of the centre-pin. This massive centre-pin was crucial in fastening the two half of the arches of the Harbour Bridge together.Be prepared to climb some stairways. There are about 200 stairs to viewing gallery of the Pylon Lookout. As such, please wear comfortable walking shoes.Please check the visiting hours before visiting. Website of Pylon Lookout: http://www.pylonlookout.com.au

Cheaper than the Bridge Climb. This is an alternative to the Bridge Climb to get some great views of the harbour and city. It's only $11, bargain. You don't get quite as high as the Bridge climb, but you are able to take your own camera and get some great shots. It's about 200 steps to the top, but you can take your time and stop at different levels to read the info about the Bridge. Great activity for a great price.
The Pylon. Walk up Pylon on the Rocks side of the bridge. A lot less expensive $13 adults/$7 Seniors that the Bridge Climb $200US. Great views, just not quite as high

my new favorite view of Sydney. For a long time I ignored the Pylon Lookout because I had already seen Sydney from so many other fantastic viewpoints. But I had a visitor in town recently and we had free vouchers so we tried it out. So glad we did! The view is amazing and the photos are some of the best I've taken of the harbour, the bridge and the skyline. You get to bring a camera (which you can't on the Bridge Climb) and you're not behind glass (like you are in the Sydney Tower). You can see in every direction and stay up there as long as you want. And its only around $10 or $12 admission.

You just have to walk across!. We enjoyed the incredible views off the bridge itself. We didn't feel compelled to take the very expensive bridge walk, but we did go into the tower museum and this is very interesting. I very highly recommend this. You can easily enjoy a good 4 hours walking across the bridge and back, as well as enjoy the museium.
Best View of the Harbour. Please take the time to walk into the Pylon near the Rocks. For only $11 you get THE best view of the Opera House and the Harbour.
Do walk the bridge. Wish we'd climbed, but ran out of time. A walk across is a great pleasure, especially if you take the time to go up one of the pylons and see the museum.

Go up the pylon!. If you don' t fancy the bridge climb-it's well worth just walking across the bridge & also going up the pylon open to the public to take in the views. A lot cheaper than the bridge climb too!

Spectacular. You can walk across it, climb it or go up in the Southeast pylon. We chose the latter. Construction under the bridge had closed the access base so we backtracked to walk the bridge to the pylon viewing area. Costs $11 AU but worth it. Much less expensive than the bridge climb although not nearly as dramatic.
Pylon. Much cheaper than a grossly over rated bridge climb! $9 good value and beautiful view, even the view from the bridge itself is great!
An engineering wonder. Gives great views of the city. Only did pylon lookout climb, excellent value at 11 dollars compared to near 200 for full bridge climb as you can use your camera

Go to the Harbour Pylon attraction for a good view of the city. You don't need to pay to do the Bridge Climb to get a good view of the harbour and the city, just go to the Harbour Pylon at the city end of the bridge, pay a rather exorbitant entrance fee (but not as much as Bridge Climb) and take in the view.

A lot of money but a once in a lifetime opportunity. We went back and forth on whether or not to spend the money because we had already spent so much money. I am definitely glad we did. They run the attraction like a factory and it's actually a good thing because they get you through the orientation quickly. It takes a good portion of the day but the view and experience is like nothing you have ever seen. The Pylon we were going to climb was only the half the way up. A once in a lifetime experience because we would ever pay that kind of money again but worth every penny even for the pictures.

Not just a pretty view. I absolutely recommend that you climb the 200 steps to the lookout point in the South Tower. A great museum at the top. You don't have to be an engineer to appreciate what an incredible undertaking this was, and why it still defines the city. I didn't find the signposting too helpful, but asked in the tourist information centre in The Rocks and they were very helpful.

Good walk across. The entrance to the walkway is quite hard to find. The pylon climb is well worth doing on the way over and gives excellent views of the harbour. Give the bridge climb a miss; at $300 per head it's too dear. There are some shops on the Milson Point end of the which are a good place for lunch before heading back.
Pylon has great view without expense. Don't bother with the bridge walk - the pylon affords you a great view without all the expense.

We climbed it!. This was an excellent experience. Scary at first climbing the ladders right next to the traffic and the trains, but as soon as you are on the bridge it is well worth it. Quite expensive but worth it, get a hat, certificate, group photo and entrance to the Pylon lookout included within the price.Have to purchase the individual photos that the guide takes of you on the bridge. Takes about an hour to get all suited and booted and kitted up with everything that you need

Great view from the pylon. Walked up from The Rocks to the bridge. Didn't want to pay the $200 each for the bridge climb this time so just went up the pylon for the $11. Wasn't as good as the bridge, but gave you a run down of the history and some good views. We enjoyed it and had other things to spend the time and money on this trip than the bridge climb tour. Lots of people out doing it though!

There is an option to the expensive walk to the top!. On one of the bridge pylons you will find a door that will let you climb up inside that pylon to the top for just under $10.00. (I believe it was the north west, but check it out for yourself.) Once at the top you can take a few pictures and get a feel for the height of the bridge, without being exposed to the elements and the wind. For my budget, and my nerves, it was a far better option that the expensive guided tour to the top via the walk over the top.
Iconic Landmark. This is such a must see..walk to the Pylon near The Rocks, up the steps for superb views..it's the best free entertainment.
Masterpiece of engineering. Did not climb it, went to the Pylon look out - it was fantastic. The exhibition in the Pylon is very informative. Would recommend.

A Must with Kids!. When we travel, my kids love walking across bridges and climbing to the highest towers. The Sydney Harbour Bridge had both experiences in one place. We walked over and up to the Pylon Museum/Lookout where we could see views of the entire harbor and neighboring parts of Sydney. We watched the rows of bridge climbers walk up along the edge of the arch and checked out the movie which told about how the bridge was built. After, we walked all the way across the bridge and contemplated going over to Luna Park but my kids thought it looked like it was more for younger kids. This is a relatively inexpensive attractiion that really takes in the best of Sydney.

Go for pylon lookout for breathtaking views over Sydney. Clearly the better alternative to see Sydney than the Sydney Tower or Bridge Climb as long as you're not willing to splurge for thrill. Lots of stairs to the top keep you in shape and you're rewarded with spectacular sights onto Sydney & Opera House.

As good as Bridge Climb with own photos and 1/30 the price!. I found myself in Sydney for a week on business recently. While spending a few spare hours on the weekend, I turned to TripAdvisor for reviews on the Bridge Climb tour of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. I'm glad I did because I found the Pylon Lookout instead.For 1/30 the price - no joke, 10 bucks versus 300 - I was able to climb to the top of the Sydney Harbour Bridge Pylon (closest to the Circular Quay side of the bridge) and look out across the city. Unlike Bridge Climb, it also included a museum on the bridge's construction and I was able to take my own photos at the top instead of paying for a "guide's" photos of me. I can't recommend the Pylon Lookout enough - it's a fantastic stop and a very reasonable price. The climb isn't too strenuous and the reward is unbeatable views, ready for you to capture with your own camera.

Very Cool - But consider Pylon Climb instead. The bridge walk is great - a unique experience for sure.I'm just suprised I can't find the Pylon Climb as a listed "attraction" here????If you are short on time or just want to save a few hundred dollars and get a view almost as good then consider the pylon climb for $9.50 a person.
